book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. To proceed: I have reviewed a transcript of a scientific course explaining the text 'Nukhbat al-Fikar' by Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - prepared by some brothers who also created an index for it. I named it: (Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'). I ask Allah the Great to accept it and make it beneficial for His creation, indeed He is the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. And peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. Dr. Abdul Aziz bin Rayyis Al-Rayyis @dr_alraies Supervisor of the Ancient Islam Website 23/ 8 / 1441 AH

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Introduction: It is known that this text is in the science of Hadith Terminology, and this science, as is not hidden, is one of the instrumental sciences leading to knowing the authenticity and weakness of Hadith. The method in commenting on this text - God willing - is as follows: 1 - Clarifying the intent of Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. 2 - Mentioning what is important in some issues if there is something calling for that. 3 - Mentioning some observations on the words of Al-Hafiz - if found -. I ask Allah to teach us what benefits us and benefit us with what He taught us, indeed He is the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Before starting the commentary on this useful text, I present some introductions: First Introduction: The student of knowledge should strive to combine the science of Hadith and the science of Fiqh (Jurisprudence), for whoever combines them strengthens his arm and his status in knowledge becomes great. Therefore, if you look at the condition of many scholars known for knowledge and famous for it, you find that they combined these two sciences. Among the great words of Imam Al-Shafi'i - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - is that he said: Whoever looks into Hadith, his argument strengthens. And he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, for the jurist needs the hadith of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, to use as evidence, and his deduction cannot be valid except after establishing its authenticity, and this is only through knowledge of the science of Hadith. Ibn Hibban spoke in his book (Al-Majruhin) about combining the science of Hadith and the science of Fiqh with extremely valuable words. Therefore, we should strive and struggle with ourselves to combine these two sciences, for the science of Hadith refers to the authenticity and establishment of the second source, while the science of Fiqh refers to understanding the Prophetic Hadith and understanding other Sharia evidences. However, it should be known that a scholar might be an imitator (Muqallid) in the science of Hadith, and this is a deficiency, but it is not correct for a scholar to be knowledgeable in Halal and Haram and be an imitator in the science of Fiqh, just as a Muhaddith might

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: be a Muhaddith and not have depth in the science of Fiqh, being a Mujtahid in the science of Hadith and an imitator in the science of Fiqh. Perfection is to combine both matters, the science of Hadith and the science of Fiqh. I ask Allah by His mercy and grace to bestow upon us all beneficial knowledge and righteous deeds, indeed He is the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Allah has blessed us in this era with a rare reviver scholar, the Allama Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. This scholar is a reviver in many chapters of religion, but what concerns me is what relates to the science of Hadith, for he is one of the most precise late scholars in knowing the authenticity and weakness of Hadith, and in precision and accuracy, for many late scholars have illusions in attribution and other things, but as for Allama Al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - rarely is such found with him. He is a scholar deeply versed in the science of Hadith, proficient, possessing mastery, knowledge, and accuracy - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Even one of them wrote a treatise critiquing Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani regarding some hadiths and their attribution to some sources... etc., so Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani pointed out in (Al-Silsilah) to respond to the one who wrote this treatise, describing him as a young man, and said: If he were knowledgeable, he would not have critiqued, for I left attributing it to such source because there is an addition which is the letter Waw, and it affects the wording of the hadith, unlike that hadith... So he spoke with valuable words - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani has great merit upon the nation of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, in the science of Hadith, for he brought it closer and made it easier. Allah bestowed upon him access to many references that many of his contemporaries did not access - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. I have sat with many who care for the science of Hadith, and they agreed that they did not know this science except by studying at first under Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani. Indeed, I met two men known, unfortunately, for attacking Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani, and when conversation took place with them, one of them said: By Allah, I did not know this science except by reading the books of Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani. He even said: I do not think anyone in these times can be a Muhaddith without having learned from his books. The other said: In my early days, I was devoted to his books and reading them. Yet, they denied his merit - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: It should be known that there is no correlation between honoring a man and knowing his status, and disagreeing with him. The scholars of Islam have commanded us to follow the evidence even if we disagree with them. So a student of knowledge who possesses the tools has the right to disagree with whomever he disagrees with from the people of knowledge using the rules of the people of knowledge, while preserving their status and rank. We have been tested in these times with those who detract from Allama Al-Albani and lower his rank, until I read one of them saying: Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani is not a Muhaddith!! He wants to deny the sun in broad daylight. I do not want to prolong this, but whoever wants to know this science should benefit from the books of Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani, especially the two Series (Al-Silsilah Al-Sahiha and Al-Da'ifa), Irwa' al-Ghalil, and the extended Takhrij of Sunan Abi Dawud, for in these books there is expansion, collection of paths, and mention of some benefits and rules that are not easily found. I ask Allah to forgive him and all Muslim scholars, and to gather me, you, and him in the highest Paradise, indeed He is the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Second Introduction: It should be known that the purpose of studying the science of Terminology is that it is an instrumental science and a means to know the terminologies of the people of knowledge in Hadith. So if the Imams of this field and its knights say: A Gharib (strange) hadith, or a Sahih (authentic) hadith, and other terms, the goal - of the science of Terminology - is to know the meaning of their words. It is a mistake for some who wrote in Terminology, who are not from the people of Hadith, to introduce definitions for terminologies not present among the Imams of this field and the early Imams of Hadith and its knights. They define some terminologies with definitions not present with them, and this is a big mistake, and this will become clear during reading the words of Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. So they define Munkar, Mahfuz, or others with definitions not present among the early scholars. What is assumed in the science of Terminology is to clarify the meaning of the scholars' usage of terms in the science of Hadith, not to introduce meanings for terminologies used by the people of knowledge or to introduce new terminologies not spoken by the early scholars, as will be explained - God willing -.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Note: The early scholars, when they spoke about Hadith, were closer to the linguistic meaning than to the terminological meaning, so most of their expressions refer to the linguistic meaning, and they did not bring a new terminology, but rather known Arabic meanings. Third Introduction: Kalam (Theology) never entered a science without corrupting it, for the Mutakallimun (Theologians) are not scholars by consensus of the people of knowledge nor jurists. Ibn Abd al-Barr - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned the consensus in his book (Jami' Bayan al-Ilm wa Fadlihi). The words of the Imams of Ahlus-Sunnah like Imam Malik, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and others regarding the prohibition of Kalam and condemning it are numerous, written and recorded. Ibn Abd al-Barr quoted part of it in his book (Jami' Bayan al-Ilm wa Fadlihi), and Qawwam al-Sunnah in his book (Al-Hujjah fi Bayan al-Mahajjah). Al-Harawi authored a complete book titled: (Dhamm al-Kalam wa Ahlihi) [Condemnation of Kalam and its People], and quoted in it useful transmissions from the people of knowledge. The scholars are concurrent in denouncing Kalam and that it is misguidance and falsehood and not permissible in Sharia. Among Kalam is the science of Logic, which is forbidden by consensus of the people of knowledge; the consensus was narrated by Al-Nawawi, Ibn al-Salah, and a group of scholars. Hence, Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - says in his book (Miftah Dar al-Sa'adah): Logic never entered a science without corrupting it. Likewise, Kalam, from which is the science of Logic, never entered a science without corrupting it. Some people might have a craving, or not be knowledgeable of the reality of knowledge, so they say: I will not be convinced of the corruption of Kalam until I study it. The least of the harms in his action is that he wastes his life in what does not benefit, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, as in Sahih Muslim from the hadith of Zaid bin Arqam, used to say: «O Allah, I seek refuge in You from knowledge that does not benefit». So how about when it contains prohibitions and what leads to misguidance, which Allah knows best about. Groups have studied this science and regretted studying it. Among them from the Mutakallimun is Al-Razi for example, who excelled in this science and regretted studying it. Among them are those from Ahlus-Sunnah who studied it to refute the Mutakallimun as Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah did, and clarified that there is no benefit in this science, rather it is a cause for misguidance. Among them is Al-Shawkani in the explanation of the hadith: «The Halal is clear and the Haram is clear», he said: I inform you about a man who studied this science and completed his study until he reached the utmost in it. Then he clarified that there is no benefit in this science, and that whoever is deceived by this science is one who has not deepened his study of it. Therefore, Kalam never entered a science without corrupting it, including the science of Hadith.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi was influenced in his book (Al-Kifayah) in some chapters by Kalam, and after him the influence by Kalam increased even more. Ibn Rajab pointed out in Sharh (Al-Ilal) Al-Khatib's influence by Kalam, saying: Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi spoke in the chapter of the addition of the trustworthy (Ziyadat al-Thiqah) and introduced the saying of the Mutakallimun into it. Fourth Introduction: A distinction should be made between the speech of the people of Hadith and the speech of the jurists in the science of Hadith and Hadith Terminology. There is a difference between the speech of the people of Hadith and the speech of the jurists, for the reliance and reference in every art is for its people. Ibn Abi Hatim narrated in his book (Al-Marasil) from his father Abu Hatim that the consensus of the people of Hadith is an authority, meaning in Hadith. Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned similar to this as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa) and Ibn al-Qayyim as in (Mukhtasar al-Sawa'iq), that the consensus of the people of every art is an authority in the art itself. It is a mistake for someone who is not specialized and knowledgeable in the science of Hadith among the jurists to speak about the science of Hadith, for whoever does that corrupts this science, as happened to Ibn al-Salah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in the chapter of the addition of the trustworthy; he introduced the speech of jurists into this chapter, and Al-Biqa'i pointed this out. Therefore, confusion occurred with Ibn al-Salah in this chapter because he mixed it with the speech of jurists, and jurists are not people of knowledge in that. Ibn Daqiq al-Eid pointed to this meaning in his book (Al-Muqtarah) when he mentioned: "without Shadh (anomaly) or 'Illah (defect)", he said: Shadh is a defect that the Muhaddithun cared about and the jurists neglected. Therefore, a distinction should be made between the speech of the people of the art and the speech of others. The speech of jurists entered the science of Hadith, and what happened in it happened. Among the great words of Al-Bulqini, narrated by Al-Sakhawi from him, is that he said: If we expanded in interpretation (Ta'wil), we would have rejected many of the defects ('Illal) that the Imams of Hadith used to identify. Expanding in interpretation and reconciling between hadiths according to the method of jurists results in rejecting many of the defects brought by the Muhaddithun, and perhaps clarifying some of this will be possible - God willing -. Fifth Introduction: The science of Hadith has knights and Imams, who are the early scholars, the predecessors, like Shu'bah, Al-Thawri, Ahmad, Ibn al-Madini, Yahya bin Ma'in, the two Razis, and their likes.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: These Imams are the reference in this science, they are its knights and its Imams, and it is not correct for anyone to contradict them. Among the subtle clarifications by Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - during his discussion on the hadith of Anas regarding running fingers through the beard in his book (Tahdhib al-Sunan), when he quoted words from Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi correcting a hadith that Muhammad bin Yahya al-Dhuhli had weakened, Ibn al-Qayyim said: "These allowances are not paid attention to by the Imams of Hadith and the doctors of its defects. They know that the hadith is defective due to Al-Zubaidi's Mursal narration of it, and they have a taste that allowances and probabilities do not intervene between them and it." Ibn Rajab - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned similar to that and said: The Imams of Hadith, if they say a saying, it is not correct for anyone to contradict them. Similarly, Ibn Hajar in his book (Al-Nukat 'ala Ibn al-Salah) said: If the Imams of Hadith and its knights speak in this science and are not contradicted, it is not correct for anyone to contradict them. All this is due to their deep-rootedness in this science and their knowledge of it, for they are the role models in it, and they are the followed Imams in knowing it. Then it should be known that we and they have two states: • First State: Matters we share with them, and they are the origin in them and it is not correct for us to dispute them, because we cannot reach a conclusion regarding the weakness or trustworthiness of a narrator except by referring to their words. The best any of us can do is to excel in collecting their words and summarizing them, so we are dependent on them. This is not just me and you, nor in our century or the previous century, but even in the time of Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi and Ibn Abd al-Barr, for these do not critique by probing the narrator's condition, but rather rely on the words of the past Imams, so how about me and you? • Second State: Matters in which they separated from us, and distinguished themselves from those after them, for they accessed matters that no one after them can access. Examples of this include: That Imam Al-Bukhari - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - asked Ismail bin Abi Owais to show him his books, so he showed him his books, and Imam Al-Bukhari - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - selected from them. Ibn Hajar mentioned this in his introduction to Sahih Al-Bukhari. We cannot reach this level, and the utmost we can do is read the scholars' words about Ismail bin Abi Owais and look into the hadith, whereas Al-Bukhari accessed his books then selected from them a selection, and this is not available to those after them.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Therefore, one should submit to the Imams and not oppose them, this is if they do not disagree. If they disagree, we use the rules of the people of knowledge that we received from them. Sixth Introduction: It should be known that the text (Matn) has an effect on the authenticity and weakness of the hadith. Some texts establish a new legal ruling, so strictness is applied to them which is not applied to others. Other texts do not bring a new ruling, so leniency is applied to them which is not applied to others. Examples of this include what Al-Bukhari narrated from Ubayy bin Abbas bin Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi from his father from his grandfather regarding the mention of the Prophet's horse, peace be upon him, which was in a garden of theirs called Al-Lakhif. Ubayy bin Abbas is weak, and his brother Abd al-Muhaimin followed him, and he is weaker than him, yet Al-Bukhari narrated it. Ibn Hajar said in (Al-Nukat): Al-Bukhari was lenient in narrating it because it is not from the hadiths of rulings and nothing results from it, so Al-Bukhari - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - was lenient in it. Therefore, this chain, if applied to another text in rulings, would not be authentic, but it was authentic in such a case. So the type of text should be scrutinized, for based on knowing the type of text, strictness or leniency in the chain is determined. Because of this, scholars were lenient in hadiths of encouragement and intimidation (Targhib and Tarhib). Al-Nawawi said in his book (Al-Adhkar): Scholars agreed on leniency in hadiths of encouragement and intimidation. And the words of Imam Ahmad, Al-Razi, and others said: If we narrate in Halal and Haram we are strict, and in encouragement and intimidation we are lenient. The reason for that, as Ibn Taymiyyah says in (Majmu' al-Fatawa) in the eighteenth volume, and similar was mentioned by Al-Shatibi in his book (Al-I'tisam), and Al-Albani in the introduction to (Sahih al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib), they said: The intended meaning is leniency in hadiths of encouragement and intimidation upon which no rulings are based. So the ruling is established by authentic evidences, thus its desirability or obligation is established, then another hadith mentions the virtue of what this hadith contained, so such is treated with leniency, with conditions such as the weakness not being severe, and so on.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: The reason for leniency in it is that Allah's bounty is vast, and how many acts of worship we perform without knowing their virtue, yet they may have virtues that only Allah knows. Allah's bounty is vast, then no Halal or Haram results from that, so leniency is applied in it unlike in others. Many make mistakes and authenticate hadiths in encouragement and intimidation while the original ruling indicated by these hadiths is not established by an authentic path, so their authentication of this hadith results in authenticating it in rulings, so strictness should be applied in such cases. An example of this: the hadith of the virtue of Dhikr upon entering the market. The hadith is weak, weakened by Ibn Adi and others. But if a man wanted to be lenient in this hadith on the pretext of leniency in hadiths of encouragement and intimidation, it is said: Authenticating this hadith results in the desirability of this Dhikr, so it returns to rulings; because what indicates desirability, obligation, prohibition, or dislike returns to rulings. No authentic hadith established the desirability of this Dhikr, then a hadith came clarifying its virtue. If a hadith authenticating the desirability of this Dhikr was established, then a hadith came clarifying its virtue, leniency would be applied in this virtue. But to base the matter on authenticating a hadith in virtue resulting in the saying of its desirability, such is not permissible. This is a matter that should be noticed, known, and realized. Seventh Introduction: This great science is grasped by much practice and application, not by theoretical matter. Some people you find prominent in studying the science of Terminology theoretically, but in application and practice they are weak and have little experience. Such a person does not have knowledge of hadiths' authenticity and weakness. I have seen some distinguished in studying the science of Terminology and expansive in it, but extremely weak in knowing hadiths as authentic or weak, and this is a big mistake. The student of knowledge should have practice, experience, and many applications until his arm strengthens and becomes strong, for this science is only grasped by much practice. Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned this, and Ibn Hajar in his book (Al-Nukat), and Ibn Rajab in his explanation of (Al-Ilal), and Ibn al-Salah in some chapters. Whoever does much Takhrij (extraction) and tries to know how scholars judged authenticity and weakness, and practices a lot, his arm strengthens and he becomes strong in this science. Therefore, I advise you to strive in that and benefit from the books of Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, and not to stop there, but I advise you to start with them and then expand after that, and rise and ascend until you refer to the Imams and knights of this science.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: After this, I begin commenting on this blessed text, and I ask Allah to forgive Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Praise be to Allah Who has always been Knowing, Capable. And may Allah send blessings upon our master Muhammad whom He sent to the people as a bearer of glad tidings and a warner, and upon the family of Muhammad and his companions and grant them abundant peace. To proceed: The compilations in the terminology of the people of Hadith have multiplied, expanded, and been abbreviated. Some brothers asked me to summarize for them the important parts of that, so I answered him to his request; hoping to be included in those paths. Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - followed the method of logicians in arrangement and division, which is the method of classification and division (Sabr wa Taqsim), and he did that for the sake of approximation and facilitation. Such a thing is not called an innovation, for the method of classification and division is indicated by the Quran, and the people of knowledge followed it before these logicians and theologians. His saying: (Some brothers asked me) A group asked him, among them Al-Zarkashi Al-Shafi'i, Al-Sakhawi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned this in his book: (Al-Jawahir wa al-Durar).

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: So I say: The report (Khabar) either has: paths without a specific number, or with a restriction to more than two, or to two, or to one. So the first is: The Mutawatir (Mass Transmitted): Useful for certain knowledge with its conditions. And the second is: The Mashhur (Famous), which is the Mustafid (Extensive) according to an opinion. And the third is Al-Aziz (Rare/Strong), and it is not a condition for the Sahih contrary to who claimed it. And the fourth is: The Gharib (Strange). And all of them - except the first - are Ahad (Singular). Among them is the Accepted and the Rejected; because deducing evidence from them depends on researching the conditions of their narrators unlike the first. And among them may occur what provides theoretical knowledge through indicators according to the chosen view. Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned that the arrival of Hadith and Khabar to us has two ways. He - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned the term Khabar (Report). It should be known that the term (Hadith), (Khabar), and (Athar) are all applied to the Hadith attributed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; therefore, Al-Majd Ibn Taymiyyah authored: (Muntaqa al-Akhbar) naming the hadiths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, Akhbar. Also, Al-Tahawi authored: (Sharh Ma'ani al-Athar) naming the hadiths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, Athar. So Khabar applies to Prophetic Hadith and others, and Athar applies to Prophetic Hadith and others. Al-Nawawi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned that the method of Muhaddithun is that Khabar applies to Hadith, and that some Khurasanis differentiated between Athar and Hadith, saying: Athar is applied to other than the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while Hadith is what is applied to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. The correct view is to say: Khabar, Athar, and Hadith are all applied to the hadiths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, his sayings, actions, and approvals. So, the arrival of the Khabar to us has two states: • First State: That it reaches the level of Tawatur (Mass Transmission). • Second State: That it does not reach the level of Tawatur, which is Ahad.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: So whatever is not Mutawatir is Ahad, and Ahad has three divisions: 1 - Gharib. 2 - Aziz. 3 - Mashhur. I begin by explaining the meaning of Mutawatir; because whatever is not Mutawatir is Ahad. Mutawatir according to terminology scholars as clarified by Al-Hafiz in his explanation of this text, which is Nuzhat al-Nazar: What a group narrated from a group whose agreement and collusion on lying is habitually impossible, from the beginning of the chain to its end, and their basis is sensory perception. So the conditions for Tawatur are: • First condition: The narrators must be a group. • Second condition: Habit precludes their agreement and collusion on lying. • Third condition: It must be from the beginning of the chain to its end. • Fourth condition: Their basis must be sensory perception, like saying: I heard, or I saw, and the like. The difference between collusion (Tawatu') and agreement (Tawafuq): Collusion is what happens intentionally, meaning if this group tried to agree on lying they would not be able to, while agreement: meaning they agree on lying without collusion. Al-Manawi mentioned this in his comments on (Nukhbat al-Fikar). Every hadith that gathers these conditions is a Mutawatir hadith, and whatever does not gather these conditions is Ahad, and Ahad has three divisions: First Division: Gharib. It is when there is one narrator in one of the layers of the chain. If it is assumed that a hadith is narrated by five from five from one from five, it is Gharib. Second Division: Aziz. It is when there are two narrators in the smallest layer of the chain. If five narrated from five from two from five, it is an Aziz hadith.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Third Division: Mashhur. It is what the narrators were a group more than two, three or more, but the conditions of Mutawatir did not apply to them. So every group from a group... etc. and the conditions of Tawatur did not apply to them, it is Mashhur. An important rule in the science of Terminology should be known: Scarcity prevails over abundance. If you want to judge a hadith whether it is Mutawatir or Ahad, and whether it is Gharib, Aziz, or Mashhur, look at the smallest layer of the chain's narrators. The consideration is for the minimum. If a thousand narrated from a thousand from a thousand from one from a thousand, it is said: It is Gharib, because the view is to the minimum. Similarly, if a thousand narrated from a thousand from a thousand from two from a thousand, the hadith is Aziz, because the view is to the minimum. Similarly, if a thousand narrated from a thousand from two from one from three, it is Gharib, for the view is to the minimum. As Al-Hafiz clarified in (Al-Nuzhah). His saying: (So I say: The report either has: paths without a specific number) His saying without a specific number: This is the Mutawatir, and this is the first division. The second division is his saying: (or with a restriction to more than two, or to two, or to one) This is the Ahad, and he indicated that Ahad are three types. His saying: (or with a restriction to more than two) This is the Mashhur. His saying: (or to two) meaning by the narration of two, and this is the Aziz. His saying: (or to one) And this is the Gharib. His saying: (So the first is: The Mutawatir: Useful for certain knowledge with its conditions) He made the Mutawatir useful for certain knowledge with its conditions, and the conditions of Tawatur were mentioned previously. It should be known that knowledge is of two types: • First Type: Necessary and certain knowledge, which is what does not need observation, deduction, or research. • Second Type: Theoretical knowledge, which is what needs observation and deduction. Hafiz Ibn Hajar made the Mutawatir useful for necessary certain knowledge, meaning without observation and deduction. In this there is a view [reservation] - and Allah knows best -; because many may narrate a single hadith and the reference of the multitude returns to a liar, or thieves who steal hadiths and multiply the paths falsely. Therefore, observation and deduction are necessary. Allama Al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - pointed this out in his comments on

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: (Nukhbat al-Fikar), and he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Al-Mu'allimi pointed to this in his comments on the book (Al-Fawa'id Al-Majmu'ah) by Al-Shawkani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. His saying: (And the second is: The Mashhur, which is the Mustafid according to an opinion) meaning what a group narrated but did not reach the limit of Tawatur. His saying: (which is the Mustafid according to an opinion) meaning that some scholars name the Mashhur Mustafid and some differentiate between Mashhur and Mustafid. Ibn Hajar clarified that discussing Mustafid is not among the topics of this art, as he clarified in his explanation of (Nukhbat al-Fikar). Some say that the abundance must be at the beginning of the chain and its end, meaning the abundance should be in the entire chain beginning and end and in between, such is called Mustafid and other than that is called Mashhur. He mentioned other opinions then said: And this is not among the topics of this art. And he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. His saying: (And the third is Al-Aziz, and it is not a condition for the Sahih contrary to who claimed it) Aziz is what two narrated as preceded, and such is not a condition for the authentic hadith. He said: (contrary to who claimed it) and the one who claimed that are the Mu'tazila, like Al-Jubba'i and others. Their disagreement should not be mentioned for their disagreement is not considered and is not used as evidence in the entire religion, so how about the science of Hadith? This was attributed to Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim in his book (Ma'rifat Ulum al-Hadith), and in this attribution there is a view [reservation], for he authenticated many hadiths by the narration of a single narrator. Al-Hakim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - only intended that the companionship of a Companion is not established except if two narrate from him, with details according to him. The important thing is that it is not a condition for the authenticity of the hadith that two narrate it, neither Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim nor others from Ahlus-Sunnah nor the Imams of this field from the people of Hadith. His saying: (And the fourth is: The Gharib) It preceded that Gharib is what a single narrator narrated, it is called Gharib. I emphasize that scarcity in this art prevails over abundance, so the least narrated layers are looked at, and based on that the hadith is described whether it is Mutawatir or Ahad, then it is looked at which division of Ahad it is, Gharib, Aziz, or Mashhur? It should be known that the term (Gharib) has a meaning among the early scholars different from its meaning among the later ones. When they say: "Gharib hadith", they mean by it that it is a weak hadith. From that is the practice of Al-Tirmidhi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, he says: This is a Gharib hadith. Meaning: Weak.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Imam Ahmad said: If you see the people of Hadith saying: Fa'idah (Benefit) or Gharib, leave it. He clarified by this that it is a weak hadith. So when scholars say: Fawa'id of Abu Tammam, Fawa'id of such, meaning his weak hadiths. This is a terminology followed by the early scholars - may Allah have wide mercy on them -. His saying: (And all of them - except the first - are Ahad. Among them is the Accepted and the Rejected; because deducing evidence from them depends on researching the conditions of their narrators unlike the first) He clarified - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - that Ahad with its three divisions needs research, deduction, and observation until it becomes clear whether it is authentic or weak? His saying: (- except the first -) which is Mutawatir. It preceded that there is a view [reservation] in this, and that Mutawatir needs research and deduction. Then he clarified that Ahad contains the Accepted and the Rejected unlike Mutawatir, and the correct view is that in all hadiths whether Mutawatir or Ahad there is the Accepted and the Rejected as preceded. His saying: (And among them may occur what provides theoretical knowledge through indicators according to the chosen view) This is a discussion on Ahad hadiths and their provision of prevailing opinion (Ghalabat al-Zann) or knowledge (Ilm). The majority of scholars hold that Ahad hadiths provide prevailing opinion. Among those who chose this is Ibn Taymiyyah in his book (Minhaj al-Sunnah) and as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa). But Ibn Taymiyyah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - clarified in a useful discussion in (Muqaddimat Usul al-Tafsir) and in (Radd al-I'tiradat al-Misriyyah 'ala al-Fatwa al-Hamawiyyah) that the Ahad hadith if surrounded by indicators provides knowledge, and attributed this to the scholars of the four schools. Even Abu Ishaq Al-Isfarayini said: The hadith narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim provides knowledge by consensus. This is an indicator that it provides knowledge, even though Abu Ishaq Al-Isfarayini is from the Mutakallimun, yet he mentioned that the hadith if agreed upon by Al-Bukhari and Muslim provides knowledge by consensus. Therefore, the Ahad report if surrounded by indicators moves from prevailing opinion to knowledge. Among the indicators: that the Ummah acts upon it, or Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrate it, or the Ummah receives it with acceptance, to other numerous indicators. Some scholars like Ibn al-Qayyim as in (Mukhtasar al-Sawa'iq) held that the Ahad report provides knowledge by mere authenticity without being surrounded by indicators, and attributed this to Malik, Ahmad, Al-Shafi'i, and a group. Then Ibn al-Qayyim said: And this knowledge varies in its strength. So it seems Ibn al-Qayyim's disagreement with those who say it provides

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: prevailing opinion is close to being verbal, because he admitted that this which provides knowledge also varies in the knowledge it provides. The matter is easy, but the following should be known: • First Matter: The Ahad report is evidence in Fiqh and practice. Many proofs indicated this, mentioned by Al-Shafi'i - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in his book (Al-Risalah), and elaborated by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in his book (Al-Faqih wa al-Mutafaqqih). Then consensus was narrated that the Ahad report is evidence for practice by a group of scholars including Ibn al-Qass, narrated from him by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in his book (Al-Faqih wa al-Mutafaqqih) and affirmed by Al-Khatib, and Ibn Abd al-Barr in the beginning of his book (Al-Tamhid), and Ibn Taymiyyah in (Daf' al-I'tiradat al-Misriyyah), and Ibn al-Qayyim as in (Mukhtasar al-Sawa'iq). • Second Matter: The Ahad report is evidence in Creeds (Aqa'id) by consensus, due to the many proofs for accepting the Ahad report in Creeds. Among them is what Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Mu'adh to Yemen and said: «You are going to a people from the People of the Book, so let the first thing you call them to be the testimony that there is no god but Allah» Hadith. He established the proof through Mu'adh, may Allah be pleased with him, and those with him, and these did not reach the limit of Tawatur according to the criterion of Tawatur among the Mutakallimun. As for the consensus that the Ahad report is evidence in the chapter of Creeds, it was narrated by a group including Ibn Abd al-Barr in the beginning of his book (Al-Tamhid) and Ibn Taymiyyah in (Daf' al-I'tiradat al-Misriyyah). After this: Mentioning Tawatur in the science of Hadith is a matter mentioned by past scholars. Among those who mentioned that is Imam Al-Bukhari, he said regarding the hadith: «There is no prayer for he who does not recite the Mother of the Quran»: A Mutawatir hadith. But Tawatur has a meaning among the Imams and knights of this art different from its meaning among Terminology scholars. What was mentioned previously of conditions for Tawatur is the saying of the Mutakallimun not the jurists nor the early Salaf Imams. The first to mention it in books of Hadith Terminology was Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, otherwise its origin is taken from the Mutakallimun. Therefore, these conditions have no mention in the speech of past scholars, neither explicitly nor implicitly. Rather, they have speech indicating the opposite, for Al-Shafi'i has speech indicating criticism of some conditions of Tawatur, and similarly Al-Darimi in his refutation of Bishr al-Marisi.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Tawatur with these conditions does not exist in Prophetic hadiths. Ibn Hibban stated this explicitly in the introduction to his Sahih, saying: The entire Sunnah is Ahad. And he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, for on these conditions there is no example for it. Al-Hazimi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned similar, and Ibn al-Najjar who is one of the Usuli Mutakallimun in Sharh (Al-Kawkab), then Ibn al-Salah in the phrase quoted by Al-Hafiz in (Al-Nuzhah) said: Unless it is claimed in the hadith: «Whoever lies about me intentionally», also 'claimed', meaning not asserted. So Tawatur in this sense does not exist in Prophetic Hadith. It preceded that the science of Hadith Terminology studies the terminologies of the people of knowledge, and it is an instrumental science not an end in itself to know Prophetic hadiths authenticity and weakness. Thus, the saying of Tawatur in this sense does not exist. • Note: Past scholars expressed Tawatur, but Mutawatir to them meant: The Abundant (Mutakathir), for their expressions as preceded are closer to the linguistic meaning. Tawatur varies; three might narrate a hadith and it be Mutawatir, and ten might narrate it and it not be Mutawatir. Ibn Taymiyyah said: That is due to the difference in the condition of narrators. Then Ibn Taymiyyah likened this to food, he said: Among food is that which if you eat a little of it you become full like meat, and among food is that which if you eat a lot of it you do not become full. He attributed this to the people of Hadith. And he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Three narrators might narrate a hadith and it be Mutawatir, five might narrate it and it be Mutawatir, and ten might narrate it and it not be Mutawatir. This is by looking at the condition of narrators. So Tawatur exists in their speech but contrary to these conditions introduced by the Mutakallimun which have no existence in the Prophetic Hadith from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: Then the Gharabah (Strangeness): Either it is in the origin of the Sanad (Chain), or not. So the first is: Al-Fard Al-Mutlaq (Absolute Singular). And the second is: Al-Fard Al-Nisbi (Relative Singular), and the application of 'Fardiyyah' to it is rare. And the Ahad report with the transmission of a 'Adl (Upright) Tamm al-Dabt (Perfectly Precise), with a connected Sanad, not Mu'allal (Defective) nor Shadh (Anomalous): Is the Sahih Li-dhatihi (Authentic by itself). And its ranks vary with the variation of these descriptions. Hence Sahih Al-Bukhari is prioritized, then Muslim, then their condition. If the precision is lightened: It is Al-Hasan Li-dhatihi (Good by itself), and with the multiplicity of its paths it becomes Sahih. If they are combined, it is due to hesitation in the transmitter where there is uniqueness, otherwise it is considering two chains. And the addition of their narrator is accepted as long as it does not occur contradictory to one who is more trustworthy. If contradicted by a more preponderant, the preponderant is Al-Mahfuz (Preserved), and its opposite is Al-Shadh. And with weakness, the preponderant is Al-Ma'ruf (Known), and its opposite is Al-Munkar (Denounced). And the Relative Singular: If another agrees with it, it is Al-Mutabi' (Follower), and if a text resembling it is found, it is Al-Shahid (Witness). And tracking the paths for that is Al-I'tibar (Consideration). His saying: (Then the Gharabah: Either it is in the origin of the Sanad, or not. So the first is: Al-Fard Al-Mutlaq. And the second is: Al-Fard Al-Nisbi, and the application of 'Fardiyyah' to it is rare) His intent by this is that strangeness is either in the origin of the chain, i.e., from the Companion, or not. The view for strangeness is not from the Companion himself but in the narrators from the Companions who are the Tabi'un, because in such research one looks at who is after the Companion not at the Companions themselves. If one narrator narrated from the Companion and the Tabi'i was one, it is strange in the origin of the chain, so it is called: Absolute Singular. But if the strangeness is in one of the layers of the chain either from a specific scholar like Shu'bah, so one is unique from Shu'bah, and so on, this is strangeness but it is called: Relative Singular.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Al-Hafiz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - made Gharib into two types, either in the origin of the chain or after that. In the origin of the chain it is called: Absolute Singular, and what is after that is called Relative Singular. Relative is like being unique from Shu'bah, such is rarely called 'Fardiyyah', but rather it is said: Gharib from the hadith of so-and-so. As for uniqueness (Tafarrud), it is applied if it is in the origin of the chain. What appears - and Allah knows best - from the practice of the Imams of the people of Hadith is that they do not notice such things. Whenever they see uniqueness and there is a benefit in mentioning uniqueness whether in the origin of the chain or otherwise, they say: No one narrated it from so-and-so except so-and-so. And they do not observe such things - and Allah knows best -. His saying: (And the Ahad report with the transmission of a 'Adl Tamm al-Dabt, with a connected Sanad, not Mu'allal nor Shadh: Is the Sahih Li-dhatihi) He began explaining the accepted and rejected hadiths. It should be known that hadiths generally are of two types: • First Type: Accepted hadiths, which are four sections: o First Section: Sahih Li-dhatihi. o Second Section: Sahih Li-ghayrihi. o Third Section: Hasan Li-dhatihi. o Fourth Section: Hasan Li-ghayrihi. • Second Type: Rejected hadiths, and discussion on it and causes of its rejection will come - God willing -. Al-Hafiz began by explaining the definition of Sahih Li-dhatihi, and mentioned five conditions for it, three of which are positive conditions and two are negative. Among the conditions are what relates to the chain only, and among them what relates to the text as well. Shadh and Mu'all relate to the text as well, while narrated by 'Adl Tamm al-Dabt relates to the chain. Shudhudh and 'Illah relate to chain and text. His saying: (with the transmission of a 'Adl Tamm al-Dabt...) First condition: To be 'Adl (Upright). Second condition: To be Tamm al-Dabt (Perfectly Precise). Third condition: To have a connected chain. Fourth condition: Not to be Mu'all (Defective). Fifth condition: Not to be Shadh (Anomalous). If these five conditions gather in a hadith, it is Sahih. If a condition from these conditions is missing, it decreases in its authenticity or becomes Hasan or Da'if (Weak), depending on the deficiency in the condition.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Al-Adl: Meaning the narrator possesses piety (Taqwa) and integrity (Muru'ah). Whoever is not like that, his hadith is not Sahih, like being an innovator or Fasiq (sinner). If the narrator is an innovator or Fasiq, his hadith is weak; because this condition he applied even in Hasan. So if this condition is missing, the hadith moves from being Sahih to being Weak. This - and Allah knows best - has a view [reservation]. As for Fisq (sinfulness), it does not prevent accepting the narration, and you do not see in the words of scholars, the Imams of this art, that they rejected a hadith from a man because he is Fasiq as long as he is truthful and precise. This is confirmed by what will come, which is that past scholars are almost unanimous on accepting the narration of the innovator which is worse than Fisq, even if he was a caller to it. Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi mentioned this in his book (Al-Kifayah) and quoted it from a group of people of knowledge and prolonged the quotation in that. Perhaps clarification of this will come more - God willing -. So, the condition of being 'Adl meaning not being Fasiq and a fortiori not being an innovator has a view [reservation] - and Allah knows best -. And Perfect Precision (Tamam al-Dabt) in the apparent wording: means reaching the highest of precision, and in modern estimations it is said: one hundred percent, because when he mentioned the deficiency of this condition he said: Hasan is what his precision is lightened. This has a view [reservation] - and Allah knows best -, and its clarification will come more in discussing Hasan. That is because among the trustworthy (Thiqat) there are those whose perfect precision decreases and they are still trustworthy. Even Al-Dhahabi has a saying implying that there is no trustworthy narrator except that he has erred, and this is in the majority. His saying: (with a connected Sanad, not Mu'allal nor Shadh) Discussion on connection will come - God willing -. However, it is said: Mu'allal, Ma'lul, or Mu'all are synonymous terms. The term (Mu'all) is found in the speech of linguists who affirmed it, and likewise the term (Ma'lul), while the term (Mu'allal) was denied by many linguists, and the matter in this is easy - God willing. The point is that Terminology scholars made 'Illah a hidden defect impugning the authenticity of the hadith. This means that the apparent matter is not called 'Illah. Al-Nawawi, Al-Iraqi, Al-Sakhawi, and a group rectified this and clarified that 'Illah applies to the hidden matter and the apparent matter, i.e., to the hidden defect and the apparent defect. The books of the Imams of 'Ilal like Imam Ali bin al-Madini, the two Razis, and Al-Daraqutni, indicate that they mention in them what was defective whether by an apparent or hidden defect. It became common among Terminology scholars

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: that they restrict 'Illah to the hidden matter. Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim spoke similarly in (Ma'rifat Ulum al-Hadith), but it might be said that his speech is regarding the majority, because the speech of the early ones is further from definition and discipline than the speech of those after them, for the later ones care greatly about definitions, and if they define a definition they want it to be inclusive and exclusive... etc. The point is that 'Illah in the speech of past scholars applies to the impugning matter whether hidden or apparent. His saying: (nor Shadh) Shadh is defined - as will come - by the contradiction of a trustworthy narrator to one who is more trustworthy, either in precision or in abundance and number. So if one contradicts a group of trustworthy narrators or those who are more trustworthy than him, it is said about it: Shadh. What appears - and Allah knows best - is that Shudhudh is broader than this, although it indicates this but it is broader than this. Everything that indicates linguistically that it deviated (Shadhdha) - i.e., was unique with a uniqueness that is not accepted - is said about it: Shadh, whether the trustworthy or the weak was unique. Clarification of this will come more - God willing -. Then let it be known that scholars' expression with the term (Shadh) in books of 'Ilal is rare or almost non-existent. I have turned over what Allah facilitated of them and did not find them expressing a hadith as Shadh, but rather they say: Munkar, Khata' (Error), and so on. Therefore, reliance regarding narrators is that they be precise, and truthful, combining truthfulness and precision, then that the chain is not disconnected between him and his sheikh, then that there is nothing in the text preventing its acceptance by contradicting others which are more authentic than it necessitating its rejection. If these matters gather in a hadith, it is an authentic hadith. As for the narrator being Muslim, this is a condition by consensus, for the disbeliever's narration is not accepted; Al-Nawawi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - narrated the consensus. His saying: (And its ranks vary with the variation of these descriptions) He spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - and this indicates that his saying: (Perfect Precision) has a view [reservation]. Perfection is not stipulated, rather he reaches a perfection in precision but it is not stipulated to be complete - and Allah knows best -. Then it should be known that precision according to scholars is of two types: precision of chest (memory), and precision of book.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: His saying: (Hence Sahih Al-Bukhari is prioritized, then Muslim, then their condition) i.e., because the ranks of Sahih vary, Sahih Al-Bukhari was prioritized over Sahih Muslim. Al-Bukhari's hadiths are authentic and Muslim's hadiths are authentic, but Al-Bukhari's hadiths are more authentic. What is on the condition of Al-Bukhari and Muslim is prioritized over what is on the condition of Al-Bukhari, and what is on the condition of Al-Bukhari is prioritized over what is on the condition of Muslim. Notes: First Note: What the two Sheikhs agreed upon is prioritized over others in general knowing that there is a difference between Muhaddithun and Jurists in the terminology of Muttafaq Alayh (Agreed Upon). Muhaddithun stipulate that the text and the Companion be the same in the two Sahihs, while Jurists, even if the Companion differed, make it Agreed Upon as long as the text is in Al-Bukhari and Muslim. Ibn Hajar benefited this in Al-Nukat. Based on this, the hadith: "Indeed, some eloquence is magic" is Agreed Upon according to Jurists unlike Muhaddithun, because Muslim narrated it from Ammar bin Yasir, and Al-Bukhari narrated it from Ibn Umar. Second Note: The hadiths of Sahih Al-Bukhari are prioritized in authenticity over the hadiths of Sahih Muslim in general not individually, as clarified by Al-Zarkashi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Third Note: Ibn Hajar verified in his book (Al-Nukat) and in (Al-Nuzhah) - which is the explanation of (Al-Nukhbah) - that it is not known from any of the people of knowledge that they preferred Sahih Muslim over Sahih Al-Bukhari. He said: There are some in the Maghreb who preferred Sahih Muslim over Sahih Al-Bukhari but intended arrangement and organization and did not intend authenticity. His saying: (then their condition) The meaning of scholars' saying: On the condition of Al-Bukhari, or condition of Muslim, should be known. The most correct opinion is that the meaning of scholars' saying: "On the condition of Al-Bukhari" or "On the condition of Muslim" is that the chain of the hadith is in the form of the chain of hadith in Sahih Al-Bukhari, or in the form of the chain of hadith in Sahih Muslim, or in the form of the chain of hadith in the two Sahihs, not that the intended meaning is the men (narrators) of Al-Bukhari and Muslim. This was verified by Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, Al-Dhahabi, Ibn al-Salah, Ibn Hajar, Al-Sakhawi, and a group of people of knowledge.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Therefore, whoever wants to say about a hadith that it is on the condition of Al-Bukhari or Muslim must look at their extraction of the narrators of the hadith in the form extracted by Al-Bukhari or Muslim or both. Then after this it is said: It should be known that Al-Bukhari and Muslim did not stipulate a condition, Abu al-Fadl bin Tahir al-Maqdisi mentioned this in Shurut al-A'immah al-Sittah. The utmost of those who speak on this speak by deduction, saying: This is on the condition of Al-Bukhari, and this is on the condition of Muslim. What appears - and Allah knows best - is that upon scrutiny it is not correct to say about a hadith that it is on the condition of Al-Bukhari nor on the condition of Muslim nor on their condition, due to the following: • First Matter: Scholars look at the text and the chain. Al-Bukhari might accept this chain for this text, and not accept this chain for another text, as mentioned in the introduction. Al-Bukhari narrated from Ubayy bin Abbas bin Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi from his father from his grandfather regarding the mention of the Prophet's horse, peace be upon him, in a garden of theirs called Al-Lakhif. This chain, if it were for another text in rulings, Al-Bukhari would not accept it. So if someone saw this chain and cited it for another text in rulings, it would become weak. Is it correct to say weak on the condition of Al-Bukhari? This is not correct in any case. So the past scholars observe the text with the chain. Al-Bukhari might be lenient in a chain considering the text, and not lenient in this chain considering another text. There are examples for this and perhaps some will be mentioned during the explanation - God willing -. • Second Matter: Imam Al-Bukhari and Imam Muslim select. It preceded that Al-Bukhari selected from the hadiths of Ismail bin Abi Owais, so he narrated what he saw as selected and authentic. It is not correct for those after them to come to any hadith of Ismail bin Abi Owais and narrate it saying: On the condition of Al-Bukhari, in the form extracted by Al-Bukhari, then say it is on the condition of Al-Bukhari. So what appears - and Allah knows best - is that it is not correct to say about a hadith that it is on the condition of Al-Bukhari or on the condition of Muslim or on their condition, due to what was mentioned. I emphasize that they did not stipulate their conditions in an apparent text. Rather, Muslim indicated in the introduction that he narrates from the first and second layer and selects from the third, unlike Al-Bukhari who narrates from the first and second. Al-Bukhari did not state this either, but it was deduced from his action. What was mentioned may be benefited from the words of Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in his book (Al-Nukat 'ala Ibn al-Salah).

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: His saying: (If the precision is lightened: It is Al-Hasan Li-dhatihi) He made the difference between Sahih Li-dhatihi and Hasan Li-dhatihi the lightness of precision. Al-Dhahabi mentioned in his book (Al-Muqizah) saying: I am in despair that a criterion exists for the Hasan hadith. Meaning he says: I despair that a criterion is mentioned for the Hasan hadith. Some thought that when Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: If his precision is lightened then it is the Hasan hadith, that he brought the criterion. This has a view [reservation]. Al-San'ani clarified this in his book (Nata'ij al-Afkar), he said - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -: And what is the criterion for lightness of precision? It preceded that the narrators of authentic hadiths vary in their precision. As an approximation: Whoever his memorization is one hundred percent, is called Sahih. Whoever his memorization is ninety percent is called Sahih. Whoever his memorization is eighty percent is called Sahih. Whoever his memorization is eighty percent compared to one hundred percent has lightened precision, yet he is called Sahih. So what is the criterion of lightness that makes the hadith Hasan? By this it is known - and Allah knows best - that there is no decisive criterion for the Hasan hadith. Therefore, one should not be strict in the criterion of the Hasan hadith. The early scholars used to include the Hasan hadith in the Sahih hadith. Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned the consensus on that, he said: Until Al-Tirmidhi came and divided the hadith into three divisions, Al-Sakhawi quoted this from him in his book (Fath al-Mughith). The division among the early scholars was Sahih and Da'if (Weak), so whatever is not Weak is Sahih, and Hasan enters into that. This is easier, although a scholar might say: This is a Hasan hadith, indicating that it is in the lowest ranks of precision, i.e., lowest ranks of authenticity, but Hasan does not exit from being Sahih. Some issues in Sahih hadith were mentioned previously. As for issues of Hasan hadith, there are several issues, some of which were mentioned during the explanation, but among the issues: • First Issue: The early scholars include Hasan hadith in Sahih hadith. Ibn Taymiyyah narrated this as a consensus as quoted by Al-Sakhawi in his book (Fath al-Mughith). Therefore, the division according to them is between Sahih and Da'if as previously clarified. This is more precise than the tripartite division due to what was mentioned that there is no precise criterion for the Hasan hadith. • Second Issue: The one who divided Hadith in terms of acceptance into Sahih, Hasan, and Da'if is Al-Tirmidhi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. He is the one famous for dividing Hadith into

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: these three divisions, and intended by them in terms of validity and rejection, as clarified by Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Hence he said: And the first to single out the Hasan hadith is Al-Tirmidhi. • Third Issue: In the speech of early scholars, there is the usage of Hasan, intending by it several meanings, either the goodness of the text, or the goodness of its wordings, or the strangeness of the text. Thus Shu'bah said: From its goodness (Hasan) I fled... to other meanings. Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - quoted this in his book (Al-Nukat). • Fourth Issue: Imam Ahmad - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: Weak hadith is more beloved to me than opinion (Ra'y). Imam Ahmad - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - does not intend the weak hadith which opposes the Sahih - i.e., the Rejected - because scholars agree that the weak hadith which is synonymous with Rejected and opposes Sahih is not used as evidence in rulings. Ibn Taymiyyah narrated the consensus as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa). Rather, Imam Ahmad's intent is: Hasan Li-ghayrihi, meaning what became accepted by its corroborations. If you look at it by itself, it is weak, and if you look at it by its corroborations, it became accepted, i.e., Hasan Li-ghayrihi. Imam Ibn Taymiyyah clarified this as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa), Ibn al-Qayyim in (A'lam al-Muwaqqi'in), Ibn Rajab in his explanation of (Al-Ilal), and Al-Shatibi mentioned similar in his book (Al-I'tisam). So Imam Ahmad's saying: "Weak hadith is more beloved to me than opinion" means the hadith that is strengthened, i.e., Hasan Li-ghayrihi. Hence Ibn Taymiyyah said: And it is the meaning of Al-Tirmidhi's saying in Hasan hadith: What is narrated from more than one path, and is not Shadh nor Mu'allal. Meaning what is strengthened by more than one path which is Hasan Li-ghayrihi. • Fifth Issue: I emphasize that there is no precise criterion for the Hasan hadith, and that Hafiz Ibn Hajar's saying: If his precision is lightened. Is not a precise criterion in differentiating between Hasan hadith and Weak hadith. His saying: (and with the multiplicity of its paths it becomes Sahih) This indicates that the hadith is strengthened by the sum of its paths, and discussing this will come - God willing -. However, strengthening the hadith by the sum of its paths such that the Weak becomes Hasan, and the Hasan becomes Sahih, is agreed upon. Ibn Taymiyyah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - narrated the consensus as in his book (Talkhis al-Istighathah), and also Al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - narrated the consensus in (Risalah fi Tahrim Alat al-Lahw wa al-Tarab). Imam Ahmad explicitly stated this

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Ahmad - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -, i.e., explicitly stated that the hadith is strengthened by the sum of its paths. The Quran indicates it. Ibn Taymiyyah said as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa): The Almighty said: {that if one of the two errs, the other can remind her} [Al-Baqarah: 282]. He said: This is evidence that the hadith is strengthened by the sum of its paths. Discussion on this will come more - God willing -. His saying: (If they are combined, it is due to hesitation in the transmitter where there is uniqueness, otherwise it is considering two chains) His saying: (If they are combined) i.e., if it is said in a hadith: Hasan Sahih. Al-Hafiz says this has two cases: • First Case: Either it has only one path, so the combination is by way of hesitation, such that the critic is hesitant whether it is a Sahih hadith or a Hasan hadith. • Second Case: That it has two paths, so one of the paths is Hasan and the other is Sahih. This is what Al-Hafiz mentioned, and this has a view [reservation] - and Allah knows best - for the practice of scholars is contrary to that. Therefore, most of what Al-Tirmidhi says: Hasan Sahih hadith. It is from the most authentic of Sahih, which is what the two Sheikhs agreed upon. Ibn Rajab - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned this in his explanation of (Al-Ilal), and Ibn Hajar in his book (Al-Nukat). Therefore, Al-Tirmidhi's saying: Hasan Sahih. Is an indication to the most authentic of Sahih mostly. • Note: The one who uses these terms the most is Al-Tirmidhi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in his Jami'. He defined one of them which is Hasan, mentioning three conditions: That it is narrated from more than one path, and is not Shadh nor Mu'allal. As for Gharib, the practice of scholars is that it means Weak as proceeded. As for saying: Hasan Sahih. The induction of Ibn Rajab and Ibn Hajar is that it is the most authentic of Sahih as mentioned. As for his saying: Not narrated except from this aspect. This is clear that he means uniqueness (Tafarrud), either absolute or relative uniqueness, and it proceeded that scholars do not scrutinize this and their usages are closer to language than to terminology. • Note: Differences in copies of Al-Tirmidhi are frequent. In some copies: Hasan hadith. In some copies: Hasan Sahih hadith. etc. The most precise - and Allah knows best - is what Al-Mizzi quoted in his book (Tuhfat al-Ashraf). So if you doubt the copies in our hands, refer to (Tuhfat

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: al-Ashraf) by Al-Mizzi, for he is a distinguished and precise scholar, so what he mentions is more reliable than others - and Allah knows best -. His saying: (And the addition of their narrator is accepted as long as it does not occur contradictory to one who is more trustworthy) i.e., the addition of the narrator of Hasan hadith and the addition of the narrator of Sahih hadith are accepted as long as they do not occur contradictory to one who is more trustworthy. This is a correct foundation. Every trustworthy narrator is accepted, his narration is accepted in principle unless he contradicts one who is more trustworthy than him. This is a clear foundation and Imam Al-Shafi'i - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - explicitly stated this, saying: It might be by being better in memorization or greater in number. This issue is called the issue of 'Addition of the Trustworthy' (Ziyadat al-Thiqah). Before delving into this issue, an important and very precise foundation should be understood: Contradiction according to scholars of Hadith differs and varies from contradiction according to scholars of Fiqh. Contradiction according to scholars of Hadith does not mean the impossibility of combining. Trustworthy narrators might narrate a hadith, then a trustworthy one is unique among them with an addition that can be combined with the origin of the hadith. But this, according to scholars of Hadith, is called contradiction even if combining is possible, as long as he added a matter upon which a ruling is based, unlike scholars of Fiqh. Therefore, Ibn Hajar's saying here: (as long as it does not occur contradictory) means contradictory according to the method of Muhaddithun not the method of Jurists, as he pointed out in (Hady al-Sari) and in his explanation of Al-Bukhari. He said: Contradiction according to the method of Muhaddithun. There is a difference between contradiction according to the method of Muhaddithun and contradiction according to the method of Jurists. According to Jurists, if one of the narrators added an addition, they say this is specific and that is general, or absolute and restricted, and they try to combine using many methods of combination. As for Muhaddithun, if a trustworthy narrator adds an addition over others upon which a ruling is based - i.e., has a meaning - it is considered an addition and researched as addition of the trustworthy, even if combining is possible. It proceeded what Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned in Tahdhib al-Sunan commenting on Ibn al-Qattan when he mentioned the hadith of Anas in running fingers through the beard, he said: "These allowances are not paid attention to by the Imams of Hadith and the doctors of its defects. They know that the hadith is defective due to Al-Zubaidi's Mursal narration of it, and they have a taste that allowances and probabilities do not intervene between them and it." Ibn al-Qattan tried to combine according to the method of Jurists but Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - refuted him. Similarly, Ibn Hajar said when he said: Contradiction according to the method of Muhaddithun. So if Muhaddithun say: So-and-so contradicted So-and-so. This does not mean that combining is impossible. Yes, combining is possible according to the method of Jurists, but he added something upon which a meaning is based and the rest did not bring it. From

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: here Al-Bulqini said, as quoted by Al-Sakhawi: If we expanded in interpretation (Ta'wil), we would have rejected many of the defects ('Illal) that the Imams of Hadith used to identify. And he spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Examples of this: The hadith of Abu Qais Al-Awdi from Huzayl bin Shurahbil from Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah. The hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah is famous in the two Sahihs and others, he said: «Leave them, for I put them in while they were pure» then he bent down and wiped over them, peace be upon him, i.e., wiped over the Khuffs (leather socks). Abu Qais Al-Awdi added an addition and said: He wiped over the Khuffs and the sandals (Na'layn). So he added: "and the sandals". This addition according to the method of Jurists can be combined; he mentioned a ruling others did not bring so it does not harm. But Muhaddithun said: Abu Qais Al-Awdi contradicted the people and brought the wording "sandals" while others did not bring this wording. Others said: Huzayl contradicted the people. Among those are Imam Ali bin al-Madini, who said: He contradicted the people of Medina, Basra, and Kufa and brought the wording "sandals". Note that he made it a contradiction. Similarly, Yahya bin Ma'in and Imam Muslim mentioned. Al-Bayhaqi quoted these quotations in his book (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra). Note that Muhaddithun expressed it as contradiction. • Note: If what preceded is understood, a door from the doors of defects opens which many have closed because they followed the method of Jurists not Muhaddithun, and thought that the meaning of "incompatibility of combination" or "contradiction" is that it is in a way where combination is impossible. They erred, the matter is not so. After this, the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy relates to several issues: • First Issue: The image of the issue is that the hadith is one, and trusted narrators narrate it in one way, then a trustworthy narrator shares with them and narrates it in another way, either stopped (Mawquf) or elevated (Marfu'), or by mentioning an addition. So the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy requires that the hadith be one, and that the trustworthy narrator shares with the rest of the trustworthy narrators and is unique in something. In other words: That the exit (Makhraj) of the hadith be one. Meaning the source must be unified. Ibn Rajab mentioned this in Sharh (Al-Ilal), Ibn Abd al-Hadi in his book (Al-Sarim Al-Munki), Muslim in his book (Al-Tamyiz), and Ibn Hajar in (Al-Nukat). So the exit of the hadith must be one.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: - Second Issue: The addition of Companions over one another is not included in the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy, rather it is accepted. Ibn Hajar mentioned this in his book (Al-Isabah) and Ibn Abd al-Hadi pointed to it in his book (Al-Sarim Al-Munki). • Third Issue: Addition of the Trustworthy is only discussed if the narrator adds an addition upon which a ruling is based, i.e., it has meaning and judgment. As for explanatory addition or other things upon which no ruling is based, they are not included in the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy. Muslim pointed to this in his book (Al-Tamyiz) and Al-Mu'allimi mentioned it in Al-Fawa'id Al-Majmu'ah. This is confirmed by the fact that the majority of scholars allow narrating hadith by meaning. This indicates that the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy is what a ruling is based upon. But if two narrators narrate one hadith with different wordings and no ruling is based on it, it is from narration by meaning and is not discussed as Addition of the Trustworthy. • Fourth Issue: The Imams of this art and its knights do not have a consistent rule in Addition of the Trustworthy. Sometimes they accept it and sometimes they reject it, and they refer that to indicators (Qara'in). A large group of people of knowledge mentioned this, like Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, Al-Ala'i, Al-Biqa'i, Ibn Hajar, Ibn Rajab, and others. They stated that they do not have a consistent method, but rather look at indicators. Therefore, whoever attributes to the people of Hadith that they accept Addition of the Trustworthy absolutely has erred, or whoever attributes to them that they reject it absolutely has erred. Rather, they look into every hadith for its indicator. There are indicators indicating acceptance or indicators indicating rejection, so indicators are looked at. • Fifth Issue: The default in a single hadith - even if its wordings differ - is lack of multiplicity. Ibn Hajar mentioned this in his book (Fath al-Bari) and this is a valuable benefit. The practice of Muhaddithun indicates this. As for Jurists, they expand and interpret difference in wordings as difference in incidents. From that is Al-Nawawi, for the hadith of Umar in a narration: «I vowed to observe I'tikaf for a night», in a narration: «a day», and in a narration: «a day (24 hours)». Al-Nawawi said: This indicates multiplicity of incidents. Al-Ala'i and Ibn Hajar refuted this and said: The story is one. So the default if the hadith is one is that it does not indicate multiplicity of incidents, but rather the incident is one. Ibn Hajar mentioned this in his explanation of Al-Bukhari - as preceded -, and Ibn Rajab mentioned similar. It is the practice of early scholars, for they make it one hadith then look, if a ruling is based on the addition they are strict. A narrator might say: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prostrated in one of the two evening prayers ('Isha'), and in some narrations: Asr prayer.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: This does not entail a ruling, so they are not strict in it. His saying: «I vowed to observe I'tikaf for a night» or «a day» or «a day (24 hours)» does not entail a ruling. But what entails a ruling is what is discussed in the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy. Many Jurists err in such cases from two aspects: o First Aspect: They attribute it to multiplicity of incidents, and it proceeded that this is wrong. o Second Aspect: They deduce rulings from it. In Sahih Muslim: «Whoever performs Wudu on Friday then comes...» and the many wordings: «Whoever performs Ghusl». Some said: This indicates non-obligation of Ghusl, although Ghusl is not obligatory due to other evidences, but this wording is not correct to rely upon because the source is one, and one must prefer between the wording of Ghusl or Wudu. Jurists do not pay attention to such things. Al-Ala'i mentioned this as preceded, and Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn al-Qayyim, and other scholars criticized Jurists for it. They said: The hadith is one, so preference must be made in it, and a ruling should not be deduced from every hadith, rather preference must be made. This is a precise and important topic. If the hadith is one and some added a wording upon which a ruling is built, strictness is applied and preference is made between wordings, and a ruling is not deduced from this and a ruling from that. Therefore, when Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned in his book (Al-Hady) the Isra' and Mi'raj and that it was mentioned in more than one hadith, he said: The literalists of Isnad went to multiplicity of incidents, he said: And the incident is one. This is a valuable benefit from Ibn al-Qayyim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. • Sixth Issue: It proceeded that the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy is if the source is one. However, it is found in the speech of knights and Imams of this art that they defect a hadith with another hadith, even if sources differ. For with his wide view and knowledge he knows that the two hadiths are one hadith, so he defects this with that. Disagreement might occur in this among them. Examples of this: Imam Al-Bukhari - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - defected what Muslim narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, met some people from the Muslims and said: «Who are you?» They said: Muslims. They said: And who are you? He said: «I am the Messenger of Allah» peace and blessings be upon him. A woman lifted a boy to him and said: Is there Hajj for this one? He said: «Yes, and for you is a reward». Narrated by Muslim from the hadith of Ibn Abbas. Al-Bukhari defected it with the saying of Ibn Abbas: "Any child who performed Hajj then reached puberty must perform Hajj another time." He defected it in his book (Al-Tarikh Al-Saghir) and some call it: (Al-Tarikh Al-Awsat) in a discussion he mentioned - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. The point of this is that he defected two hadiths whose sources did not agree

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: This might be done by Imams of Hadith, and this is frequent in the practice of Al-Daraqutni and others. Ibn Rajab - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - pointed this out in his explanation of (Al-Ilal). This is useful and a valuable topic. Two hadiths might be defected even if they have different sources, but it is not said this is the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy, rather this is defected by that. I mentioned it as a digression so it doesn't get confused with the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy. • Seventh Issue: Uniqueness (Tafarrud) is a defect cared for by early scholars, with which they defected much, and neglected by later scholars. Imam Muslim spoke about Uniqueness in his book (Al-Tamyiz), and Ibn Rajab in Sharh (Al-Ilal) and quoted it from the early Imams, and others from the people of knowledge mentioned it. Uniqueness might share with Addition of the Trustworthy and might be solitary. Meaning: If narrators share in narrating a hadith then one of them is unique with an addition, this is called uniqueness and called Addition of the Trustworthy. But if others did not share with him and he was unique with the entire hadith, this is the topic of Uniqueness. Examples of this - and Allah knows best -: Hadith of Asim bin Kulayb, from his father from Wa'il bin Hujr, regarding the description of the Prophet's prayer, peace and blessings be upon him. Asim bin Kulayb was unique with this hadith, and the likes of him, his uniqueness is not tolerated as clarified by Imam Ali bin al-Madini. Therefore, the one who mentioned this narration the most is Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih, and Abu Dawud and others mentioned parts of it. Imam Ali bin al-Madini defected the uniquenesses of Asim bin Kulayb. Uniqueness is a defect that should be scrutinized. Imam Ahmad mentioned that the uniqueness of a trustworthy narrator is treated with strictness, and said: What the great Imams like Al-Thawri and others were unique with might be weakened. Ibn Rajab quoted this in Sharh (Al-Ilal), and Ibn Rajab spoke about this with useful words in Sharh (Al-Ilal).
