Therefore, if a scholar is unique with a hadith, this hadith should be scrutinized, and whether the likes of him can tolerate uniqueness, and so on... And whether he was unique from a Sheikh whom he accompanied more or not? To other meanings. This is a defect neglected by later scholars to the extreme, and cared for much by early scholars, and it is extremely useful in dealing with hadiths. I mention an example of Addition of the Trustworthy in addition to what preceded: Asim bin Kulayb narrated from his father from his grandfather the description of the Prophet's prayer, peace and blessings be upon him. A group narrated it from Asim including Al-Thawri, Ibn Uyaynah, Shu'bah, and others.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: A group narrated from Al-Thawri, and Mu'ammal bin Ismail was unique from Al-Thawri, mentioning in it that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, placed his hands on the chest in prayer. Mu'ammal bin Ismail is unique in this. Muhammad bin Yusuf Al-Firyabi, who is among the most trustworthy people in Al-Thawri, and others followed him but did not bring this addition. Then a group followed Al-Thawri including Ibn Uyaynah, Shu'bah, and others and did not bring it. All this indicates that the addition of mentioning placing hands on the chest is Munkar (Denounced) and Shadh (Anomalous) and not authentic; because Mu'ammal bin Ismail contradicted the trustworthy narrators and brought it, in addition to Asim bin Kulayb being solitary with the hadith as established previously. Hence Ibn al-Mundhir said: No hadith is authentic from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding placing hands on the chest. Imam Ahmad said in Masa'il Abi Dawud: I dislike placing hands on the chest. Another example: The previously mentioned hadith of Wa'il bin Hujr was narrated by a group. Among those who narrated it from Al-Thawri as preceded is Al-Firyabi and others. But the hadith was narrated by a group from Asim bin Kulayb, then from Asim bin Kulayb a group narrated it. Then Abdul Razzaq Al-San'ani was unique from one of them, and brought an addition: "He said he pointed with his finger then prostrated". Ibn al-Qayyim in his book (Al-Hady) followed by our Sheikh Ibn Uthaymin - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - went to say that pointing with the finger between the two prostrations is desirable. This addition is Munkar and Shadh, Abdul Razzaq contradicted people in it. Hence jurisprudentially you do not find scholars mentioning this issue except Ibn al-Qayyim and those who followed him as Allama Al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - clarified. As for Hadith-wise, it is Shadh and Munkar, not acted upon by early scholars. Measure upon this, for there are many examples that should be studied and mastered. This topic, the topic of Addition of the Trustworthy, many issues are built upon it. Among its most important topics are what preceded of issues, and the most important of these issues is knowing the meaning of contradiction and incompatibility according to the early Muhaddithun, not Jurists. His saying: (If contradicted by a more preponderant, the preponderant is Al-Mahfuz (Preserved), and its opposite is Al-Shadh. And with weakness, the preponderant is Al-Ma'ruf (Known), and its opposite is Al-Munkar (Denounced)) Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - divided contradiction into two types: • First Type: Contradiction of a trustworthy narrator to one who is more trustworthy than him, either in number or memorization. If a trustworthy narrator contradicts one who is more trustworthy than him either in number or memorization, the narration of the trustworthy one is rejected and called Shadh, and the narration of the trustworthy ones or the more trustworthy is accepted and called Mahfuz. So the rejected is called Shadh, and the accepted is called Mahfuz.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: - Second Division: The weak contradicts the trustworthy. He made the weak narrator's hadith rejected firstly for his weakness and secondly for his contradiction, naming it Munkar (Denounced), and made the trustworthy's narration accepted, naming it Ma'ruf (Known). It is said: Munkar and its opposite is Ma'ruf. Ibn Qutlubugha mentioned in his explanation of (Nukhbat al-Fikar) that the method of early scholars is contrary to this. He spoke the truth - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - for the early scholars use Mahfuz more than they use Ma'ruf, but they use Mahfuz in opposition to error. Meaning a weak narrator might contradict other weak narrators, but others are more trustworthy than him so it is said: The path of the more trustworthy is Ma'ruf, even if it is rejected, and it might be said: Mahfuz, even if it is rejected. • Note: Muhaddithun might say: This path is Sahih (correct/sound), not meaning it is established from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but rather it is not an error. They might express it saying Mahfuz or Ma'ruf, not intending that it is Sahih and established from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but intending it is not an error like the other path. If you flip through books of 'Ilal, you see them saying: And the Mahfuz from So-and-so... And the Sahih from So-and-so. They do not mean it is established, but rather this face is correct and the opposite face is error. Then authenticity and weakness are researched in the correct face. They express the correct face which opposes the error as Ma'ruf, and it is said Mahfuz, and it is said Sahih. Ma'ruf is found in their speech but less used. Therefore, they do not differentiate between the contradiction of a trustworthy to one more trustworthy or the contradiction of a weak to trustworthy ones, contrary to what Hafiz Ibn Hajar mentioned. This is supported by what Abu Dawud narrated from the hadith of Hammam bin Yahya, from Ibn Jurayj, from Al-Zuhri, from Anas, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to remove his ring when entering the toilet. Abu Dawud said: This is a Munkar hadith, Hammam contradicted... etc. Hammam bin Yahya is trustworthy, yet he expressed it saying: Munkar. Therefore, every error is called Munkar, whether from a trustworthy or a weak narrator, i.e., every rejected contradiction according to the method of Muhaddithun is called Munkar, whether from a trustworthy or weak narrator, and whether opposing trustworthy or weak narrators. This benefits us in what will be mentioned in Shawahid (Witnesses) and Mutaba'at (Follow-ups) - God willing -.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: His saying: (And the Relative Singular: If another agrees with it, it is Al-Mutabi' (Follower), and if a text resembling it is found, it is Al-Shahid (Witness). And tracking the paths for that is Al-I'tibar (Consideration)) Al-Hafiz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned three terminologies: Shahid, Mutabi', and Tatabbu' (Tracking). The meaning of Mutabi': If a narrator narrates a hadith and you find another narrator agreeing with this narrator, it is called Mutabi'. If a narrator narrates a hadith textually and you find another text agreeing with this text, it is called Shahid. So Shawahid are in texts and Mutabi' in narrators. I'tibar is searching for Shawahid and Mutaba'at. His saying: (And the Relative Singular) i.e., Relative Singular unique from an Imam... etc. as preceded. The more correct - and Allah knows best - is to say: Absolute Uniqueness. Any uniqueness for which you find a follower is called: Mutabi', or a text witnessing for it is called Shahid, even if it was absolute uniqueness - i.e., complete - because a scholar might think it is from absolute uniqueness, but after searching finds a follower for it, so it becomes clear it is not absolute uniqueness. Meaning: A Tabi'i might be unique from a Companion in a hadith, so it is thought to be absolute uniqueness, but after searching it becomes clear he has a follower. So this is more inclusive than saying in Relative or Absolute Singular. Al-Hafiz differentiated between Mutabi' and Shahid. In the usage of early scholars, they do not differentiate between these two matters. Their usage is closer to linguistic meaning than terminological meaning, so the matter with them is broad in applying Mutaba'ah and applying Shawahid. Then, among the most important topics of the science of Hadith: Studying when a hadith is strengthened by Shawahid and Mutaba'at, and when it is not strengthened? The basis of this issue is what preceded, that strengthening a hadith by another is indicated by the Book, Consensus, and the practice of Imams of Hadith. Allah Glory be to Him said: {that if one of the two errs, the other can remind her} [Al-Baqarah: 282]. Ibn Taymiyyah used this as evidence as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa). Ibn Taymiyyah narrated consensus as in (Talkhis al-Istighathah) that hadith is strengthened by Shawahid and Mutaba'at. Similarly, Al-Albani in his book (Tahrim Alat al-Lahw wa al-Tarab). As for the practice of Muhaddithun, Imam Ahmad and others from the people of Hadith explicitly stated this, and their words are many in this. Ibn Rajab and others clarified this, that a hadith is strengthened by another. This is theoretically unproblematic. The problem is in application. Strengthening hadith by Shawahid and Mutaba'at relates to issues: • First Issue: That what has severe weakness is not strengthened by Shawahid and Mutaba'at. Ibn al-Salah mentioned this, and others mentioned it. So whoever has severe weakness is not strengthened. Among those who mentioned this

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: as a foundation is Ibn Hajar in (Al-Nukat). The narration of a liar is not strengthened, and the narration of Shadh as Ibn al-Salah said is not strengthened, and clarification of this will come more - God willing -. Rather, sometimes the multiplicity of paths only increases the hadith in weakness, as Ibn al-Qayyim said in his book (Jala' al-Afham), and Al-Mu'allimi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned in the introduction to (Al-Fawa'id Al-Majmu'ah) that multiplicity of paths might only increase the hadith in weakness. Then he mentioned that later scholars became lenient in strengthening hadith by multiplicity of paths. Similar to this was mentioned by Ahmad Shakir in his book (Al-Ba'ith Al-Hathith). Even Al-Suyuti - who is among the lenient later scholars as Al-Albani says - stated that the narration of a liar is strengthened if paths multiply, as in (Tadrib al-Rawi), and this is a mistake, and contrary to the method of early scholars. • Second Issue: The hadith intended to be strengthened by multiplicity of paths, if it contradicts what is stronger than it, is not strengthened. Al-Bayhaqi mentioned this as quoted by Al-Sakhawi in his book (Fath al-Mughith). So multiplicity of paths if contradicting what is stronger is not strengthened. • Third Issue: Multiplicity of paths if contradicting the Fatwas of Companions is not strengthened. Imam Ahmad pointed to this regarding Wudu with leftover water of a woman. This might be branched from the previous or be an independent issue. If Companions give Fatwas, then a hadith comes intended to be strengthened by paths and its result contradicts Fatwas of Companions, it is not strengthened, because Fatwas of Companions are authority. • Fourth Issue: Imam Ahmad said: Munkar is Munkar forever. This is among the precious and precise points in strengthening hadith by sum of paths. Every hadith where it becomes clear that the narrator erred in it, being a trustworthy contradicting one more trustworthy in memory or number, or weak contradicting one more trustworthy; it falls and is not strengthened because it is an illusion (Wahm). I cannot count the number of practices by many later scholars where they do not pay attention to such things. A narrator might contradict trustworthy narrators, then they bring this addition which is an error and strengthen another hadith with it. This is not correct; because Munkar is Munkar forever as Imam Ahmad said. Hence Ibn al-Salah said: Among what is not strengthened is Shadh, because Shadh is error as preceded. • Fifth Issue: Consideration for strengthening hadith by another hadith... etc., has no consistent criterion, as clarified by Ibn al-Salah, and he said in his book (Ma'rifat Ulum al-Hadith) which is the famous Muqaddimah of Ibn al-Salah, he said: It is only known by much practice. Indicators might sometimes indicate lack of strengthening, so it is not strengthened.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Examples of this: «There is no Wudu for him who does not mention the name of Allah upon it». Ahmad said: No hadith is established in it. If this hadith came with a sum of paths, and if these hadiths were established, it would indicate that Tasmiyah (saying Bismillah) is a condition. This is refuted by the fact that Uthman bin Affan in the two Sahihs, Abdullah bin Zaid bin Asim in the two Sahihs, and Ibn Abbas in Al-Bukhari, narrated the description of the Prophet's Wudu, peace be upon him, in detail, especially Uthman, and did not mention saying: "Bismillah". This indicates that these paths do not strengthen each other. If they were authentic, they would indicate that saying "Bismillah" is a condition. How can it be a condition when these and others did not mention it? While they mentioned the description of the Prophet's Wudu, peace be upon him, in detail? Therefore, indicators must be looked into when strengthening a hadith by sum of paths. This is only obtained by much practice as clarified by Ibn al-Salah - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned in the explanation that Mutaba'ah (Follow-up) might be deficient (Qasirah) and might be complete (Tammah). Meaning: The narrator who brought a ruling, after consideration another narrator is found following him, it is said: Complete follow-up. But if another narrator is found following his Sheikh and not following him, it is said: Deficient follow-up.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: Then the Accepted: If free from contradiction, it is Al-Muhkam (Decisive). If contradicted by its like: If combination is possible, it is Mukhtalif al-Hadith (Different Hadith). If the later one is established, it is Al-Nasikh (Abrogator), and the other Al-Mansukh (Abrogated). Otherwise, preference (Tarjih), then stopping (Tawaqquf). Then the Rejected: Either it is due to omission (Saqt) or impugnment (Ta'n): So Omission: Either it is from the beginnings of the chain from a compiler, or from its end after the Tabi'i, or other than that. So the first is: Al-Mu'allaq (Suspended). And the second is: Al-Mursal (Hurried). And the third: If it is by two upwards consecutively, it is Al-Mu'dal (Perplexing). Otherwise, Al-Munqati' (Broken). Then it may be clear or hidden. So the first: Is perceived by lack of meeting, hence the need for history. And the second: Al-Mudallas (Obfuscated) and comes with a format presuming meeting: like 'An (From), and Qala (Said). And likewise Al-Mursal Al-Khafi (Hidden Mursal) from a contemporary who did not meet. His saying: (Then the Accepted: If free from contradiction, it is Al-Muhkam. If contradicted by its like: If combination is possible, it is Mukhtalif al-Hadith. If the later one is established, it is Al-Nasikh, and the other Al-Mansukh. Otherwise, preference, then stopping) It appears to me - and Allah knows best - that it is not correct to discuss this in the science of Hadith, because it relates to Dirayah (comprehension), and Hadith Terminology relates to Riwayah (narration). So such should not be discussed in books of Hadith Terminology but in books of Usul al-Fiqh (Principles of Jurisprudence). The other matter: Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - made Mukhtalif al-Hadith (Different Hadith) applicable if combining is not possible. This implies if combining is possible, the topic of Mukhtalif al-Hadith is not discussed. This has a view [reservation]. Ibn al-Salah disagreed with him and clarified that Mukhtalif al-Hadith includes what can be combined and what cannot be combined. This is evidenced by the practice of Imam Al-Shafi'i in Mukhtalif al-Hadith, Ibn Qutaybah in his book (Ta'wil Mukhtalif al-Hadith), Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Mushkil al-Hadith) etc. The practice of scholars indicates that they included in books of Mukhtalif al-Hadith what can be combined and what cannot be combined, whereas Al-Hafiz's apparent practice restricted it to what can be combined.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: His saying: (Then the Rejected: Either it is due to omission or impugnment) The author - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - finished with the Accepted and moved to the Rejected. He clarified that rejection is due to either omission or impugnment, i.e., returns to two matters, either omission or impugnment. It might be said - and Allah knows best -: Rejection returns to three matters: • First Matter: Omission, i.e., Interruption. • Second Matter: Impugnment, i.e., Weakness in the narrator. • Third Matter: Contradiction, for a trustworthy narrator's hadith might be rejected even if he is not impugned due to contradiction. Al-Hafiz mentioned contradiction but included it in impugnment. The matter is easy in this. If three causes were stated, it would be more correct - and Allah knows best - because contradiction might be from a trustworthy narrator whose memorization is not impugned. His saying: (So Omission: Either it is from the beginnings of the chain from a compiler, or from its end after the Tabi'i, or other than that. So the first is: Al-Mu'allaq. And the second is: Al-Mursal. And the third: If it is by two upwards consecutively, it is Al-Mu'dal. Otherwise, Al-Munqati') Al-Hafiz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned that Omission - i.e., Interruption - has cases. The first case is to be from the compiler's Sheikh and is called Mu'allaq. So the compiler like Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawud, Muslim, or others, if he narrates a hadith and does not mention his Sheikh but mentions his Sheikh's Sheikh, or Sheikh of his Sheikh's Sheikh, but did not mention his Sheikh, here the interruption is from the beginnings of the chain from the compiler, so it is called Mu'allaq. Interruption might be from the end of the chain, i.e., before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, i.e., from the Companion by the Tabi'i narrating it from the Companion, so it is called Mursal. Interruption might be in any side of the chain other than the beginnings and ends, and is called Munqati'. Interruption might be due to interrupting two consecutively, so it is called Mu'dal. This is a summary of what Al-Hafiz presented. To approximate that with numbers: Suppose the compiler's Sheikh is number one, narrating from number two from number three from number four from number five who is the Companion, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: If assumed he dropped number one, it is called Mu'allaq. If he dropped number five the Companion and the Tabi'i narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it is called Mursal. If he dropped in the middle of the chain like number three only, it is called Munqati'. If he dropped two consecutively, i.e., number two and number three, it is called Mu'dal. He might drop number one and two and it is called Mu'allaq. He might drop number one, two, and three and it is called Mu'allaq, because the compiler's Sheikh dropped. And because there are two drops it is called Mu'dal, so it is said Mu'allaq and Mu'dal. He might drop the entire chain and say: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said. It is said: Mu'allaq he dropped his Sheikh, and said Mursal he dropped the Companion, and said Mu'dal. Measure upon this. This is what Al-Hafiz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - established and it is famous among Terminology scholars. After this we return to the text and take some issues related to it. His saying: (Then the Rejected: Either it is due to omission or impugnment) Omission: Interruption. Impugnment: Weakness. Discussion on it will come. Omission - i.e., Interruption - is weak according to people of knowledge because the intermediary is unknown as Ibn Abd al-Barr said in the beginning of his book (Al-Tamhid) when he spoke about Mursal. He said: And it is weak according to people of knowledge because the intermediary is unknown and not known. Hadiths of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, are treated with caution fearing that the intermediary is weak. This is the reason for scholars rejecting Interruption. When Imam Muslim mentioned the Mursal hadith - which has interruption by the Tabi'i dropping the Companion - he mentioned that scholars of Hadith reject it, as mentioned in the introduction to Sahih Muslim. The reason is ignorance as preceded, because it is not known who was dropped. So the default in Interruption is rejection. But an indicator might indicate acceptance of Interruption even if the default is rejection. The indicator might be Isnad-related or Text-related. As for Text-related indicator, Al-Bukhari narrated from the hadith of Hanzalah bin Abi Sufyan from Salim bin Abdullah bin Umar, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, supplicated against Suhayl bin Amr and Al-Harith bin Hisham. In this narration he named those supplicated against. The connected narration in Al-Bukhari from Ibn Umar did not name those supplicated against. This narration is Mursal; because it is from the narration of Hanzalah bin Abi Sufyan, from Salim bin Abdullah bin Umar, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Yet Al-Bukhari was lenient and included this Mursal narration, because no ruling is based on it. The connected narration in the two Sahihs says he supplicates against so-and-so and so-and-so and did not name them. In this narration he named them. This does not entail a ruling. The verse was revealed: {Not for you is the decision} [Al Imran: 128] to the end of the hadith. Among Text-related indicators: What Malik narrated in Al-Muwatta and Abu Dawud and others from Abu Umamah bin Sahl bin Hunaif, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that a man struck his father with an evil eye (Nabat Abahu). The hadith is Mursal, because Abu Umamah bin Sahl is a Tabi'i and did not meet the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him - so he did not witness the story, yet Malik included it in Al-Muwatta. The default in what Malik includes in Al-Muwatta is that it is proof, and this hadith likewise. The reason for leniency in it is that this story relates to his family, so such becomes famous among his family, so they were lenient in it. This is another Text-related indicator. As for Isnad-related indicator, it is the narration of Abu Ubaidah bin Abdullah bin Masoud from his father. The narration of Abu Ubaidah bin Abdullah bin Masoud from his father is a disconnected narration, for Abu Ubaidah did not meet his father Abdullah bin Masoud. Ali bin al-Madini, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, and other people of knowledge stated the disconnection. Yet, they agreed on accepting it. Yaqub bin Shaybah narrated the consensus, saying: People of knowledge studied it and saw it as upright. Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned similar as in (Majmu' al-Fatawa), and Ibn Rajab established this in Sharh (Al-Ilal). The reason for their accepting it is that they saw his narration as upright. This is supported by the fact that it is a son's narration from his father, so they were lenient in this indicator. Therefore, scholars accept the narration of Abu Ubaidah from his father, even if they declare the disconnection. This is an Isnad-related indicator. Among the hadiths narrated from this path: What Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Abu Dawud narrated from the hadith of Abu Ubaidah bin Abdullah bin Masoud, from his father, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when he sat in the first Tashahhud, it was as if he was sitting on heated stones (Radf) - meaning out of haste - then he would stand up. Radf: Stone heated by fire. This indicates hastening in the first Tashahhud and not prolonging it. Al-Tirmidhi said after narrating it: And the practice is on this according to the people of knowledge. Ibn Rajab said: Al-Tirmidhi's saying: And the practice is on this according to the people of knowledge, indicates consensus on the issue. He mentioned this in another issue in his explanation of Al-Bukhari.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Therefore, the people of knowledge are for not prolonging the first Tashahhud, unlike the second Tashahhud. The point is that this is an Isnad-related indicator they were lenient with, otherwise the default is not to accept. This is an important topic. The people of Hadith look at indicators and care for that. Among the words of the great reviver Allama Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - is that he said: The science of Hadith is not (one plus one equals two), but rather indicators are looked at in it. His saying: (Al-Mu'allaq) Among those famous for suspending hadiths is Abu Dawud in his Sunan and more than that. Among those famous for suspending as well is Imam Al-Bukhari, and he has a method. He suspends the hadith, he and others, but the speech of people of knowledge became famous regarding Al-Bukhari and they singled out discussion on him due to their care and study of him. They said: Al-Bukhari's Mu'allaqat are two types: • First Type: With a formula of uncertainty (Tamrid), like Al-Bukhari saying: It is mentioned (Yudhkar) from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, or: It is mentioned from Ibn Abbas. • Second Type: With a formula of certainty (Jazm), he might say: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said. Silah said. Ammar said... etc. As for what he asserted with certainty, it is authentic to the one he asserted it from. If he said: Silah said, Ammar said. Then it is authentic to Silah. As for what is after Silah, you look at the chain. If he asserted it from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it is authentic from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. But if Al-Bukhari suspended it saying: It is mentioned... etc., Ibn Hajar said in (Al-Nukat): If it is a hadith from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he cited it as evidence, it is either Sahih, Hasan, or Weak strengthened by others. As for Imam Muslim's Mu'allaqat, they are few, and he connected all of them except one hadith, which is the hadith of Abu Jahm, which contains removing the patterned curtain. Otherwise, all his suspended hadiths he connected - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him -. Also among those famous for suspension is Abu Dawud as preceded. His saying: (And the second is: Al-Mursal) Mursal according to the method of people of Hadith is rejected as preceded in the words of Imam Muslim in the introduction to his Sahih, and indicated by the words of others. This is looking at the chain as narration (Riwayah), it is rejected, because the intermediary is unknown as preceded in Ibn Abd al-Barr's words. As for comprehension (Dirayah), they accept Mursal considering other matters, considering Shawahid and Mutaba'at, and considering that it did not bring a new ruling so leniency is applied... etc., as clarified by Al-Nawawi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - in his explanation of

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Muslim, and Ibn Rajab in Sharh (Al-Ilal) who said: Ibn Jarir said: Rejecting Mursal is an innovation that happened after the two hundreds. His intent: rejecting it from the aspect of Dirayah and argumentation, not from the aspect of Riwayah. As for Dirayah and argumentation, it is not rejected absolutely, rather it is looked into as Al-Shafi'i clarified in his book (Al-Risalah), and Ibn Abd al-Hadi explained this in his book (Al-Sarim Al-Munki), and Ibn Rajab in Sharh (Al-Ilal). So, considering Riwayah it is rejected. Considering Dirayah it is not rejected absolutely, but the type of Mursal is looked at, and whether it has Shawahid or not, and whether it brought a new ruling or not? ... etc. Then it should be known that Mursals of Companions are accepted by consensus as clarified by Ibn Hajar and others, except that they do not accept Mursals of young Companions, i.e., those who saw the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and were young and did not narrate from him, like Tariq bin Shihab and his like. Hafiz Ibn Hajar stated this in his book (Al-Isabah) and book (Al-Nukat). So scholars' saying that Mursals of Companions are accepted: means those fit for bearing (Tahammul). As for those not fit for bearing due to young age, their Mursals are not accepted. This should be detailed so it is not thought that their saying Mursals of Companions are accepted includes even those not fit for bearing, like Tariq bin Shihab and his like. His saying: (If it is by two upwards consecutively, it is Al-Mu'dal. Otherwise, Al-Munqati') The practice of past scholars is that they apply Mursal to any interruption, whether on Mu'allaq, on Munqati' in the sense of Terminology scholars, and on Mursal in their sense. So any interruption they call Mursal, as indicated by Ibn Abi Hatim's book on Marasil, and Abu Dawud's book on Marasil. A group of people of knowledge mentioned this like Al-Sakhawi and others, that they apply Mursal to any interruption, and do not restrict it to interruption by dropping the Companion and narration of Tabi'i as preceded. Similarly, Munqati' (Interruption) is applied to any interruption even if consecutive. Their saying: Mu'dal, is applied to interruption of two consecutively, and they also apply Mu'dal to what is difficult (Mu'dal) in understanding from the aspect of text. His saying: (Then it may be clear or hidden. So the first: Is perceived by lack of meeting, hence the need for history. And the second: Al-Mudallas and comes with a format presuming meeting: like 'An, and Qala, And likewise Al-Mursal Al-Khafi

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: from a contemporary who did not meet) These are precise topics. His saying: (may be clear or hidden. So the first: Is perceived by lack of meeting) like a Tabi'i narrating from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, like Abu Al-Aliyah, Ata, Al-Hasan, or others. It is known by history through lack of meeting, that this is Mursal. His saying: (hence the need for history) by looking at the date of birth of this one and date of death of this one, and so on for those below that from one narrator narrating from another narrator, and measure upon this. So the first which is clear is perceived by lack of meeting, and this is known to Muhaddithun, unlike others. His saying: (And the second...) i.e., the hidden. Hidden applies to two types: Mudallas (Obfuscated), and Mursal Khafi (Hidden Mursal). The difference between Mudallas and Mursal Khafi: according to what Al-Hafiz - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - established is that the Mudallas has narrated from his Sheikh hadiths he heard and gave the impression he is narrating from him other hadiths he did not hear, and came with a format not explicit in updating (Tahdith). As Imam Muslim narrated from the hadith of Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira: «No people gathered in a house of the houses of Allah...» Hadith. Al-Tirmidhi said: Al-A'mash said: I was told (Huddithtu) from Abu Salih. This indicates that Al-A'mash did not hear it from Abu Salih. In Sahih Muslim he said: "From" ('An) and did not come with an explicit formula in hearing. Al-A'mash heard hadiths from Abu Salih, but this hadith he did not hear, so he is called Mudallis. So, the Mudallis heard hadiths from his Sheikh and gave the impression he heard other hadiths he did not hear, provided the formula is not explicit in hearing, because if it was explicit in hearing and he did not hear it, he would be a liar. Mursal Khafi is one who narrates from a narrator he realized and was contemporary with, but did not hear from him, so he narrated from him with a formula presuming hearing and not explicit. So the difference between Mursal Khafi and Mudallis: That Mudallis heard hadiths and gave impression he heard other hadiths he did not hear. As for the one sending Hidden Mursal, he did not hear anything but could have heard, and both came with a formula presuming hearing and not explicit. His saying: (... from a contemporary who did not meet) i.e., it is possible for him to meet. Notice his saying: (like 'An, and Qala) because they are not explicit in hearing. This is the difference between Mudallis and Mursal via Hidden Transmission, or Mudallas and Mursal via Hidden Transmission. This is according to Al-Hafiz's method. Al-Bazzar and Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi preceded him in that. Al-Iraqi said in (Al-Taqyid wa al-Idah): The method of Muhaddithun is contrary to the practice of Al-Bazzar

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: and Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi, which is that they apply Mudallis to the one sending Hidden Mursal. The comprehensive term for it is the linguistic meaning which is Tadlis (Obfuscation), that there is obfuscation in it. This is what is benefited from the words of Al-Khatib in his book (Al-Kifayah) and Ibn al-Salah in his introduction. What appears - and Allah knows best - is that scholars describe the one sending Hidden Mursal as Mudallis, but they might not describe him and might describe him. The comprehensive term is Tadlis, and it includes Hidden Sending and known Tadlis. Important issues arise in Tadlis: • First Issue: Ruling of Tadlis. Its ruling fundamentally is permissible, because it is not explicit in lying but rather it is equivocation (Tawriyah), although it is better not to do it. But fundamentally it is permissible, because it is not lying, and it is a usage that spread among Muhaddithun, so it is permissible. This is common among people of knowledge, contrary to those who were strict in it out of piety or saw its prohibition. • Second Issue: Tadlis generally is two types: o First Type: Tadlis of Sheikhs, and Tadlis of Isnad. Intended by Tadlis of Sheikhs: He narrates from his Sheikh with different names, titles, and Kunyas giving the impression he is more than one Sheikh while he is one Sheikh. It has motives and reasons. o Second Type: Tadlis of Isnad. It is to give the impression of hearing from this Sheikh while he did not hear from him, as preceded in Al-A'mash's saying: I was told from Abu Salih, and in Sahih Muslim: From Abu Salih. Most research in books of Hadith and Terminology is Tadlis of Isnad, because authenticity and weakness are built upon it. They research Tadlis of Sheikhs to distinguish the narrator, but the frequent research is Tadlis in Isnad. • Third Issue: Not every Mudallis narration is rejected if he does not come with an explicit wording in hearing. Rather, the narration of one whose Tadlis is frequent and dominant in his hadith relative to his narrations is rejected. He might be prolific in narration like Abu Ishaq, and might do much Tadlis but it is little relative to his narrations. Similar is Al-A'mash, his Tadlis is much but little relative to his narrations. Ali bin al-Madini mentioned this, saying: The narration of the Mudallis is rejected if he does it frequently. Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi narrated it from him, and Ibn Hajar quoted it in (Al-Nukat).

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Abu Hatim said in (Al-Ilal) when he mentioned Al-A'mash's narration from Mujahid: I fear he did not hear it from him, because he has few narrations from him. Note he looked at scarcity and abundance, but here scarcity not in all his narrations but in his narration from this specific person. So if a narrator does Tadlis, his hadith is not rejected absolutely. Rather it is rejected if his Tadlis is frequent relative to his narrations, so if he narrates a hadith possible of hearing it is rejected. Yaqub Al-Fasawi mentioned that the narration of Al-A'mash, Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i, and Al-Thawri is authentic, and that is - and Allah knows best - because their Tadlis is little relative to their narrations. If you say: How do I distinguish who had little Tadlis relative to his narration or much? It is said: By matters. Sometimes scholars themselves state it. If they state it, it is rejected as Ahmad stated regarding Ibn Jurayj, and as others stated regarding Muhammad bin Ishaq the author of Siyar and Maghazi, and measure upon this. They state that if he comes with a formula not explicit in hearing, it is not accepted. Sometimes this is known by looking at the practice of the authors of the two Sahihs, Al-Bukhari and Muslim. Often if they narrate frequently from a narrator described with Tadlis with a wording not explicit in hearing, and it becomes clear by research or scholars' text that he did not state hearing in other places, it indicates that his Tadlis is little relative to his narrations. Al-Subki asked Al-Mizzi about Mudallisin in the two Sahihs and that they used 'An'an (said 'From'), did they hear from them in another place? Al-Mizzi said: Their hearing from him was not established in another place, but this is said out of good opinion of the two Sahihs. Ibn Hajar quoted this in (Al-Nukat). So if the authors of Sahih, Al-Bukhari and Muslim, narrate a hadith by narration of a Mudallis with 'An'an and his declaration of hearing is not known in another place, this is an indication that his Tadlis is little relative to his narrations. Thus other indicators are researched. Among what became famous with later scholars is that they reject the narration of Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i if he uses 'An'an, and Al-A'mash if he uses 'An'an. This has a view [reservation]. The default is that the narration of Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i is accepted as Yaqub Al-Fasawi mentioned, and as is the practice of Al-Bukhari and Muslim in their Sahihs. Similarly Al-A'mash's narration is accepted, except regarding whom he narrates little from like Mujahid, as stated by Abu Hatim in Al-Ilal, and measure upon this. • Note: It might be established with a Hadith scholar that So-and-so did Tadlis, yet he accepts his hadith, due to external indicators as preceded that they accept the narration of the interrupted (Munqati') for external indicators. Like the hadith of Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira: «No people sat in a house of the houses of

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Allah...», Muslim was lenient in it and extracted it in his Sahih, because it has witnesses, established from Abu Sa'id in Sahih Muslim. Then if you contemplate its meaning, you won't find it bringing a new ruling, so Imam Muslim - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - was lenient in it. It preceded that they are lenient in Interruption for a Text-related indicator or Isnad-related indicator. • Fourth Issue: If the narrator is known and famous for frequent Tadlis, his hadith is not accepted until he states hearing. Imam Muslim stated this in his book (Al-Tamyiz), Imam Ahmad - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - mentioned this in the narration of Ibn Jurayj, and others mentioned it regarding other narrators, like Ibn Adi in his book (Al-Kamil). So if the Mudallis is famous and frequent in Tadlis relative to his narrations, he is not accepted until he states hearing. I saw some contemporaries falling into innovation saying: The narration of the Mudallis is accepted whether he did it frequently or not even if he narrated with a formula not explicit in hearing, claiming that the early Salaf were on that. He erred and fell into a major innovation upon which many errors are built. The words of Imam Ahmad and Muslim in (Al-Tamyiz) and other people of knowledge preceded. So one must differentiate between who frequented Tadlis relative to his narrations and who did not frequent as detailed previously. His saying: (And likewise Al-Mursal Al-Khafi from a contemporary who did not meet) The author - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - will speak about stipulating hearing and meeting... etc. But Mursal via Hidden Transmission which is sending from whom he did not hear and could have heard from but did not hear from with a formula bearing hearing, this is called Hidden Mursal, and is called Tadlis as preceded. Attention should be paid to an important matter: when studying hadiths, it is not sufficient to look at the narrator's trustworthiness. Rather, if the formula is not explicit in hearing, one must refer to books of hearing (Sama'). Scholars' words on So-and-so not hearing from So-and-so have been singled out in compilations and mentioned in books of biographies, as mentioned by Al-Mizzi in (Tahdhib al-Kamal) and Ibn Hajar in (Tahdhib al-Tahdhib). Bashar Awad mentioned it in his footnote on (Tahdhib al-Kamal) and mentioned many benefits from Mughultay and others. Al-Ala'i singled out a useful book on that which he named: (Jami' al-Tahsil), and Al-Iraqi also wrote a book titled: (Tuhfat al-Tahsil), including what Al-Ala'i mentioned and adding to it.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Among the useful books in this is a new printed version of Tuhfat al-Tahsil, its verifier mentioned in the footnote many benefits related to hearing and lack thereof. Also Taqrib al-Tahdhib was printed by Hassan Abdul Mannan, and he mentioned Al-Hafiz's words and added to that by mentioning hearings and lack thereof. This is extremely useful, apart from the person of Hassan Abdul Mannan and his badness and Al-Albani speaking against him - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - but his transmission and attribution concern me. Also among what is useful are the books of Allama Muqbil Al-Wadi'i, for he is interested in this. Among them: (Ahadith Mu'allah Zahiruha Al-Sihhah). This is an extremely valuable book, mentioning precise defects, including hearings and others. To other books. So care should be given to hearing and lack thereof. How many hadiths were authenticated and it was proven that the narrator did not hear from his Sheikh, sometimes proven he did not hear from him in the hadith itself and sometimes did not hear from him at all. Examples of this: What Abu Dawud narrated from the hadith of Khalid Al-Hadhdha from Abu Al-Aliyah, from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in Sujud Al-Tilawah: «My face prostrated to the One who created it, and split its hearing and sight...» Hadith. Abu Dawud mentioned that Khalid Al-Hadhdha narrates it from a man from Abu Al-Aliyah. This indicates that Khalid Al-Hadhdha did not hear it. Ibn al-Salah in his introduction, and Ibn Rajab in Sharh (Al-Ilal) benefited that the early scholars deduce the narrator's lack of hearing from the narrator by the fact that in places he introduces a man between them and sometimes two men, so they deduce by this that he did not hear from him. Therefore, care should be given to such and it should be scrutinized. I saw some wanting to strengthen Aisha's hadith in Sujud Al-Tilawah: «My face prostrated to the One who created it and split its hearing and sight...» with what is in Muslim from the hadith of Ali that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say in his prostration: «My face prostrated to the One who created it, and split its hearing and sight...». It is said: It is not correct for this to be a witness for that, because this is in all prostrations, and the research is in Sujud Al-Tilawah. So it is not correct for this to be a witness for that. This is from the leniency of later scholars in Shawahid. An example of their leniency in Shawahid in what we are dealing with: Abu Dawud narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say between the Yemeni Corner and the Black Stone: «Our Lord, give us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire». In its chain is an unknown narrator and it is not authentic. I saw some authenticated it because it was established from Umar that he used to say that in the entire Tawaf. It is said: There is a difference between Tawaf

text: as a whole and saying it is desirable between the two corners. Such is not correct to be a witness for it. These issues need precision and knowledge.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said: Then the Impugnment: Either it is due to the lying of the narrator, or accusing him of that, or grossness of his mistake, or his heedlessness, or his Fisq (sinfulness), or his Wahm (illusion), or his contradiction, or his ignorance, or his innovation, or badness of his memory. So the first is: Al-Mawdu' (Fabricated). And the second is: Al-Matruk (Abandoned). And the third is: Al-Munkar (Denounced) according to an opinion. And likewise the fourth and fifth. Then Wahm (Illusion): If discovered through indicators and gathering paths: It is Al-Mu'allal (Defective). Then Contradiction: If it is by changing the context: It is Mudraj al-Isnad (Interpolated in Chain), or by merging a Mawquf with a Marfu': It is Mudraj al-Matn (Interpolated in Text), or by advancing or delaying: It is Al-Maqlub (Inverted), or by adding a narrator: It is Al-Mazid fi Muttasil al-Asanid (Addition in Connected Chains), or by substituting him and there is no preponderant: It is Al-Mudtarib (Disturbed). Substitution may occur intentionally for testing. Or by changing with the context remaining: It is Al-Musahhaf (Misspelled) and Al-Muharraf (Distorted). It is not permissible to intentionally change the text by reduction and synonym except for a scholar of what alters meanings. If the meaning is hidden, explanation of Gharib (Strange words) and clarification of Mushkil (Problematic) is needed. Then Ignorance: Its cause is that the narrator may have many descriptions so he is mentioned by other than what he is famous for, for a purpose. They authored Al-Muwaddih concerning it. Or he may be scarce [in narration] so taking from him is not frequent. They authored Al-Wuhdan concerning it. Or he is not named for brevity. In it is Al-Mubhamat (Vague ones). The Mubham is not accepted even if vaguely described with modification wording according to the most correct view. If named and only one narrated from him: He is Majhul al-Ayn (Unknown in Person). Or two upwards and he was not authenticated: He is Majhul al-Hal (Unknown in Condition), which is Al-Mastur (Covered). Then Innovation: Either with [belief] causing disbelief, or causing Fisq. So the first: The majority do not accept its holder. And the second: Accepted is he who was not a caller [to it] according to the most correct view, unless he narrates what strengthens his innovation, then he is rejected according to the chosen view, and Al-Juzajani, Sheikh of Al-Nasa'i, stated this explicitly.

book_title: Continuing the Look at Refining 'Nukhbat al-Fikar'
text: Then Bad Memory: If it is permanent, it is Al-Shadh according to an opinion. Or emergent, it is Al-Mukhtalit (Mixed). Whenever the one with bad memory is followed up by a considered [narrator], and likewise the Mastur, the Mursal, and the Mudallas: Their hadith becomes Hasan not by itself, but by the sum. His saying: (Then the Impugnment: Either it is due to the lying of the narrator) This is clear, meaning the narrator lies about the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. If the narrator lies against the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, his hadith is not authentic but fabricated as will be explained. His saying: (or accusing him of that) Known by two things: That he is unique in narrating a hadith contradicting the rules of Islam, or being known for lying in people's speech. If he is known for his lying in people's speech, his hadith is not accepted. His saying: (or grossness of his mistake) Meaning abundance of his mistake. His saying: (or his heedlessness) Meaning being heedless, not mastering when narrating hadiths. His saying: (or his Fisq) Meaning being Fasiq. Fasiq according to Ahlus-Sunnah is the committer of a major sin who did not repent from it, as explained by Al-Saffarini in his poem, and indicated by the speech of others. Some said: One whose sins dominated. This has a view [reservation]. Rather, whoever committed one major sin and did not repent from it is Fasiq according to Ahlus-Sunnah. It preceded that Fisq is not a cause for rejecting hadith as previously clarified. His saying: (or his Wahm) Meaning he narrates hadiths while doubting their authenticity by way of illusion. His saying: (or his contradiction) Discussion on contradiction preceded. His saying: (or his ignorance) Discussion on ignorance will come. The default in ignorance is that it is rejected, because only the trustworthy is accepted in the hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, which is based on precaution. His saying: (or his innovation) Discussion will come that innovation is not a cause for rejecting hadith. His saying: (or badness of his memory) Meaning his illusion equaled his precision, or his illusion dominated. This is a summary of what Al-Hafiz clarified in his explanation of Al-Nukhbah in his book (Al-Nuzhah). Then after that he will mention the ruling of each hadith. This which he will establish has a view [reservation], because he made the Fabricated the hadith of the liar. This absolutely has a view [reservation]. No doubt the liar's hadith is fabricated, but it might

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text: Also described as 'Fabricated' (Mawdu') is what is not actually so. Among what Ibn Taymiyyah verified when it was asked: Are there fabricated hadiths in Musnad Ahmed or not? He said: If by the narration of a liar intentionally, then no. But if it is meant that someone erred so the hadith became fabricated, then yes, meaning it became fabricated without intent. Therefore, Al-Hafiz mentioned these ten causes and then mentioned their rulings. This codification and division is questionable, and scholars only differ in judgment by looking at the text (Matn) and the condition of the narrator as previously explained.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: The first is the Fabricated (Mawdu'), the second is the Abandoned (Matruk), the third is the Denounced (Munkar) according to one opinion, and likewise the fourth and fifth. Then the Illusion (Wahm): if it is discovered through indicators and gathering paths: it is the Defective (Mu'allal). Then Contradiction: if it is by changing the context: it is Mudraj al-Isnad (Interpolated in Chain), or by merging a suspended (Mawquf) narration with a raised (Marfu') one: it is Mudraj al-Matn (Interpolated in Text), or by advancing or delaying: it is the Inverted (Maqlub), or by adding a narrator: it is the Addition in Connected Chains (Mazid fi Muttasil al-Asanid), or by replacing it with no preponderant factor: it is the Disturbed (Mudtarib). Replacement may occur intentionally for testing. Or by changing [the letters] while the script remains the same: it is the Misplaced Dotting (Musahhaf) and Misplaced Voweling (Muharraf). It is not permissible to intentionally change the text by omission or synonyms except for a scholar who knows what alters meanings. If the meaning is obscure, it requires an explanation of the Strange (Gharib) and clarification of the Problematic (Mushkil). Then Ignorance (Jahalah): its cause is that a narrator may have many descriptions and is mentioned by other than what he is famous for, for a purpose; they wrote 'Al-Muwaddih' regarding this. 
His saying: (The first: The Fabricated): Fabricated is the narration of a liar. His saying: (The second: The Abandoned): Meaning the one accused of lying. His saying: (The third: The Denounced according to an opinion): Meaning one whose mistake is excessive. This is questionable as previously mentioned, for the early scholars used 'Munkar' to mean contradiction and uniqueness; thus mere uniqueness which is not accepted is called Munkar. His saying: (...and likewise the fourth and fifth): In any case, this division with this precision is questionable as previously explained. His saying: (Then the Illusion: if it is discovered through indicators and gathering paths: it is the Defective): It indicates the Defective hadith is what is proven to be an error by gathering paths, and this is correct. However, the term "Illah" (Defect), although famous for hidden defects, is applied to both hidden and apparent defects as previously explained. But the greatest way to know the hadith defective by a hidden defect is gathering paths, as stated by Yahya bin Ma'in, Ali bin al-Madini, and Imam Ahmed - may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
His saying: (Then Contradiction: if it is by changing the context: it is Mudraj al-Isnad... or by replacing it with no preponderant factor: it is the Disturbed): He mentioned contradiction then listed sections under it: 
• Section One: Mudraj al-Isnad (Interpolated in Chain), by changing the context. It has forms, including: A narrator narrates the first part of a hadith, and another narrates the second part, then someone comes after them and narrates the full hadith from both, giving the impression that both narrated it completely. This is called Mudraj al-Isnad; this is one of its forms.
• Section Two: Mudraj al-Matn (Interpolated in Text). This is inserting words into the text that are not from the speech of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. It may be at the beginning, end, or middle. An example is what Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from Ibn Umar and Aisha: "Bilal calls the Adhan at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls it. He was a blind man who would not call it until it was said to him: Morning has come, morning has come." This was narrated by Al-Bukhari, and it [the description of him being blind] is interpolated at the end of the hadith and is not from the Prophet's speech. Books have been written on this. The point is whatever is inserted into the text that is not from the Prophet's speech is called Mudraj in the text. 
Warnings:
Warning 1: The default is lack of interpolation, and it is not asserted unless evidence indicates it, as scholars establish in Fiqh and commentaries, such as Al-San'ani in *Al-Subul*. Among hadiths where interpolation is not conceded is: "Whoever among you is able to extend his white blaze and white limbs, let him do so." The correct view is that it is not interpolated, as is the practice of Muslim, and Al-Khatib did not mention it in his book on Interpolation, nor is there authentic evidence indicating it is interpolated, contrary to Al-Mundhiri and those who followed him.
Warning 2: The interpolated part is not proof like the Hadith because it is not the Prophet's speech. It might be the companion's speech, so it would be proof under conditions, or the speech of someone below him.
Warning 3: Interpolation is known by things including: 1. The arrival of a detailed narration separating the interpolated part.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
2. By the narrator explicitly stating it. 3. By the statement of some knowledgeable Imams. 4. By the impossibility of the Prophet, peace be upon him, saying it. Ibn Hajar noted this in *Al-Nuzhah*.
• Section Three: By advancing or delaying, it is the Inverted (Maqlub). Advancing and delaying can be in the name, flipping the narrator's name, or in the text as came in a narration: "Until his left hand does not know what his right hand spends." This is an inversion in the text, because the correct version is "Until his right hand does not know what his left hand spends."
• Section Four: The Addition in Connected Chains (Al-Mazid fi Muttasil al-Asanid). If you contemplate this type, you find that Hafiz Ibn Hajar in *Al-Nukat* listed it as rejected; so it is a rejected addition according to Al-Hafiz, not an accepted one. The form of 'Addition in Connected Chains' is: A hadith is narrated with a chain, then another chain comes with an additional narrator, and this addition in the other chain is rejected, so it is called 'Addition in Connected Chains'. Al-Hafiz mentioned in the explanation: For this addition to be clearly rejected, two things are required:
 o First: The first chain without the addition must have the student explicitly declaring hearing from his Sheikh.
 o Second: The one who did not add it must be more trustworthy than the one who added it, so the narration of the one who added it is rejected.
Thus, Al-Hafiz presented 'Addition in Connected Chains' as rejected, and Ibn al-Salah preceded him in this in his Introduction. However, the practice of Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi - who was the first to mention this type and wrote a book on it - is that he made some of it rejected and some accepted, as mentioned by Ibn Rajab in the explanation of *Al-Ilal*, because Al-Khatib's book did not reach us, but Ibn Rajab mentioned this about him and agreed with him. Therefore, the correct view is that 'Addition in Connected Chains' has two parts: a rejected part and an accepted part. Whatever indicators show is rejected is rejected, and whatever indicators show is accepted is accepted. It should not be categorized solely as rejected as Ibn al-Salah and then Ibn Hajar did. The early Hadith scholars do not use the term:

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
"Addition in Connected Chains", but rather they express it by saying: "So-and-so's mention is an error" or they say: "His mention is correct and the error is in omitting him," using synonyms indicating this. Thus, according to early scholars, it may be accepted or rejected, or both faces may be valid—mentioning the intermediary may be correct and omitting it may be correct. This occurs if the narrator has extensive narrations like Al-Zuhri and Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i and their likes, so it is possible he narrated it via more than one path, with and without addition. So, 'Addition in Connected Chains' falls into three categories: sometimes the addition is rejected, sometimes accepted, and sometimes both (addition and omission) are accepted. 
His saying: (OR BY REPLACING IT WITH NO PREPONDERANT FACTOR: IT IS THE DISTURBED [MUDTARIB]): This is the fifth section. Sometimes disturbance occurs among narrators; one narrates it one way, another a different way, with no preponderant factor (Murajjih). It is said: This is disturbed (Mudtarib), and we cannot prefer one because it is disturbed. Disturbance occurs in text and chain, as clarified by Ibn al-Salah and mentioned by Ibn Hajar in his explanation. The topic of disturbance has issues, but the most important thing to know is that Al-Hafiz establishes it happens in text and chain as he explained, and that it exists in the absence of a preponderant factor; if a preponderant exists, it is not called disturbance. The correct view - and Allah knows best - and the practice of early Hadith scholars is that disturbance is mentioned whether a preponderant exists or not. Whenever difference is found, it is called disturbance. A preponderant may exist so one aspect is acted upon, or none exists so all are abandoned. This is their practice; they do not restrict it to the absence of a preponderant. Disturbance is revealed by gathering paths, and it is treated like the 'addition of a trustworthy narrator' discussed earlier: sometimes accepted, sometimes rejected. One must scrutinize disturbance in the text: does a legal ruling depend on it or not? The source must be one. It is close to the topic of 'addition of a trustworthy narrator' and overlaps with it.
His saying: (REPLACEMENT MAY OCCUR INTENTIONALLY FOR TESTING): A narrator may be subjected to testing by others, so they swap the chain.
His saying: (OR BY CHANGING [THE LETTERS] WHILE THE SCRIPT REMAINS THE SAME: IT IS THE MISPLACED DOTTING [MUSAHHAF] AND MISPLACED VOWELING [MUHARRAF]): This is the sixth type, with sections under it. What Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar established is that Musahhaf

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
and Muharraf mean the shape of the word is the same, but the difference is in vowels (Harakat) or dots. By this, Al-Hafiz - may Allah have mercy on him - distinguished between them. He made Musahhaf and Muharraf share the word shape, but distinguished by dots or vowels. However, the practice of scholars before him did not differentiate between Musahhaf and Muharraf. They mostly used "Tashif" (Misplacement). They might apply it to a complete change of name, or even a change in the word's drawing, as found in the speech of Al-Shafi'i and others. Thus, early scholars mostly use "Tashif". They might use "Tahrif", but "Tashif" is dominant. Furthermore, they do not restrict Tashif to dots and Tahrif to vowels as Al-Hafiz established in his explanation of *Al-Nukhbah*. Rather, they make Musahhaf general for dots, vowels, and even the drawing of the word. Ahmad Shakir - may Allah have mercy on him - clarified this in his footnotes on *Alfiyat al-Suyuti*, noting that the early scholars did not differentiate between them, and the matter is simple.
His saying: (IT IS NOT PERMISSIBLE TO INTENTIONALLY CHANGE THE TEXT BY OMISSION OR SYNONYMS EXCEPT FOR A SCHOLAR WHO KNOWS WHAT ALTERS MEANINGS): A disagreement occurred among scholars regarding narrating Hadith by meaning. Defining the point of dispute: What is used for worship by its wording, like Adhkar (supplications), cannot be narrated by meaning, as mentioned by Al-Suyuti and Al-Sakhawi. Al-Suyuti even mentioned that 'Jawami al-Kalim' (concise comprehensive speech) cannot be narrated by meaning. As for what is worshipped by its wording like Adhkar, this is clear, as in the hadith of Al-Bara' who said: "And your Messenger whom You sent," and the Prophet corrected: "And your Prophet whom You sent," clarifying his error because it is worshipped by its wording. As for 'Jawami al-Kalim' mentioned by Al-Suyuti, it is possible it is so, depending on the narration by meaning.
• Warning: It should be known that if a narrator narrates a hadith by meaning and errs, the Hadith scholars and Imams of this art and guardians of the Sharia will clarify his error. This has happened often, for Allah preserves His religion. Ibn Rajab mentioned examples, and others mentioned that some narrators erred in hadiths because they narrated by meaning and erred in doing so. After this: The most correct of the two scholarly opinions, which is the view of the majority, is that narrating Hadith by meaning is permissible. It is the view of Al-Hasan and others. The strongest evidence for this - and Allah knows best - is that Allah mentioned to us

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
the stories that happened to previous prophets, and He mentioned them to us by meaning, even though they were in their languages and not in Arabic, yet He mentioned them to us in Arabic. Thus, narration by meaning is valid.
Warnings:
• Warning 1: Al-Mu'allimi - may Allah have mercy on him - said: The fear in narrating by meaning is only in verbal hadiths (sayings), not actions. He mentioned this in the intro to *Al-Tankil*. He spoke the truth, may Allah have mercy on him, because the action-based hadith is recounted and interpreted by the narrator, unlike the verbal hadith which is based on hearing.
• Warning 2: Ibn Hajar mentioned in *Al-Nuzhah*, and others mentioned, that the strongest evidence for the permissibility of narrating by meaning is the permissibility of translating the meanings of the Quran. It is said: This evidence is questionable; because translating the meanings of the Quran is not narrating the Quran by meaning, but rather translating the meaning from one language to another. There is a difference between translating meaning from language to language and narrating the wording with another meaning [in the same language]. Therefore, it is questionable - and Allah knows best - and the evidence is what was previously mentioned.
His saying: (IF THE MEANING IS OBSCURE, IT REQUIRES AN EXPLANATION OF THE STRANGE [GHARIB] AND CLARIFICATION OF THE PROBLEMATIC [MUSHKIL]): This also has no relation to the science of Terminology (Mustalah), because this relates to Dirayah (understanding/comprehension), and our discussion is in Riwayah (narration).
His saying: (THEN IGNORANCE [JAHALAH]: ITS CAUSE IS THAT A NARRATOR MAY HAVE MANY DESCRIPTIONS AND IS MENTIONED BY OTHER THAN WHAT HE IS FAMOUS FOR, FOR A PURPOSE; THEY WROTE 'AL-MUWADDIH' REGARDING THIS. OR HE MAY HAVE FEW NARRATIONS SO TAKING FROM HIM IS NOT FREQUENT; THEY CLASSIFIED 'AL-WUHDAN' [THOSE WITH ONE NARRATOR] REGARDING THIS. OR HE IS NOT NAMED FOR ABBREVIATION; THIS INCLUDES THE AMBIGUOUS [MUBHAMAT]. THE AMBIGUOUS IS NOT ACCEPTED EVEN IF MADE AMBIGUOUS WITH A WORD OF MODIFICATION [TA'DIL] ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW): He mentioned - may Allah have mercy on him - that among the causes for rejecting a hadith and impugning a narrator is being unknown (Majhul). He made ignorance a cause for impugning the narrator, and this is correct, because the unknown's condition is not known, and accepting hadiths is based on precaution; only the report of a trustworthy person is accepted, so the narration of the unknown is not accepted. He mentioned causes of ignorance: The narrator might have many descriptions and be mentioned by other than what he is famous for. They wrote concerning this - and Allah knows best - *Al-Muwaddih* (The Clarifier) - with stress - meaning: what clarifies those with many descriptions. Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi - may Allah have mercy on him - wrote a book on this. The second cause for ignorance is his saying: (OR HE MAY HAVE FEW NARRATIONS SO TAKING FROM HIM IS NOT FREQUENT; THEY CLASSIFIED 'AL-WUHDAN' REGARDING THIS) meaning one from whom only one person narrated. His saying: (OR HE IS NOT NAMED FOR ABBREVIATION) is the third cause for ignorance.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
His saying: (THIS INCLUDES THE AMBIGUOUS [MUBHAMAT]): It should be known that there is a difference between the Ambiguous (Mubham) and the Neglected (Muhmal). The Muhmal is when a man is named but what distinguishes him is not mentioned, so it is said: "Muhammad told us." He does not name his father or anyone else, so Muhammad is not known and is called Muhmal. As for the Mubham, it is said: "A man told me." Just like that, it is not known who this man is. Or he says: "The trustworthy one told me." This is Mubham because he did not name this man. So there is a difference between Mubham and Muhmal. Then he digressed - may Allah have mercy on him - in mentioning the Mubham, saying: (THE AMBIGUOUS IS NOT ACCEPTED EVEN IF MADE AMBIGUOUS WITH A WORD OF MODIFICATION ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW). He stated that this Mubham is not accepted even if a man says about him: "The trustworthy one told me," because it is not known who this man is; he might be trustworthy to him but not to others. So this ambiguous authentication is not accepted, and this is the correct view.
His saying: (IF HE IS NAMED AND ONLY ONE PERSON NARRATES FROM HIM: HE IS 'MAJHUL AL-AYN' [UNKNOWN ENTITY]. OR TWO OR MORE, AND HE IS NOT AUTHENTICATED: HE IS 'MAJHUL AL-HAL' [UNKNOWN CONDITION], WHICH IS 'AL-MASTUR' [THE VEILED]): Al-Hafiz divided the unknown into two types:
• Type One: Majhul al-Ayn (Unknown Entity).
• Type Two: Majhul al-Hal (Unknown Condition).
He said regarding Majhul al-Ayn: One from whom only one person narrated. Meaning: and this man was not authenticated, so he is called Majhul al-Ayn. But if two or more narrated from him and he was not authenticated, he is called Majhul al-Hal. So Majhul al-Ayn and Majhul al-Hal share that they are not authenticated, except that Majhul al-Ayn has one narrator from him, and Majhul al-Hal has two or more. This is what Al-Hafiz established. However, Ibn Abd al-Barr and Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi mentioned something additional to this. They said: If the man is famous for asceticism or generosity... etc., even if only one person narrated from him, he is called Majhul al-Hal. So he rises from Majhul al-Ayn to Jahalat al-Hal. Al-Khatib's words imply that Hadith scholars hold this view. So, one from whom only one person narrated but is famous for either asceticism, generosity, or bravery is called Majhul al-Hal. This is correct and closer to the meaning of Majhul al-Hal. Both Majhul al-Ayn and Majhul al-Hal are weak and [their narrations] are not valid. I draw attention to issues regarding the Unknown, and what should be mentioned might come later, but I mention it and refer to it later:

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
• Issue One: The Unknown is rejected as previously mentioned because he is unknown and his condition is not known, and the hadiths of the Prophet, peace be upon him, are based on precaution, so verification is necessary. However, some scholars use the term "Jahalah" (Ignorance/Anonymity) to mean he is not famous for narration, just as Imam Ahmed applied "Jahalah" to Abd al-Rahman bin Wa'lah, who is one of Muslim's narrators and has been authenticated; he meant that he is not famous for narration. It should be known that scholars have specific usages known by looking into biographical books and comparing their speech with others, etc. So "Jahalah" may be used to mean lack of fame.
• Issue Two: Some scholars' authentication is not relied upon because they are lax in authenticating, such as merely Ibn Hibban mentioning a man in his book *Al-Thiqat*. It does not indicate his trustworthiness; in fact, he once mentioned a man and said: "I do not know him nor his father," yet he counted him among the trustworthy (Thiqat) based on his principle that the default state of Muslims is probity (Adalah). Such is not accepted. Similarly, Al-Ijli; Al-Mu'allimi mentioned in his book *Al-Tankil* and *Al-Anwar Al-Kashifah* that Al-Ijli is lax, especially regarding the Successors (Tabi'in). So if you find a narrator among the Successors mentioned in *Al-Thiqat* only by Ibn Hibban and authenticated only by Al-Ijli in his book *Al-Thiqat*, it is not accepted because they are known for laxity, especially Al-Ijli regarding Successors. Examples of this - and Allah knows best - are when a scholar says: "So-and-so is among the trustworthy of the people of Yamama" or "trustworthy of such-and-such..." Such usage also intends probity by authentication, because general authentication means general probity, like the book *Mashahir Ulama' al-Amsar* by Ibn Hibban, which uses this often, and others. If it is said: "From the trustworthy of such-and-such," the intent is probity, not "Thiqah" meaning precision (Dabt). This is something that should be regulated.
• Issue Three: Some scholars do not narrate except from a trustworthy person. Such a person's hadith is not accepted absolutely [as authentication for his sources], like Imam Ahmed and Imam Malik and others, for they do not narrate except from a trustworthy person. Abu Hatim said: "Unless it becomes clear that he is weak" - meaning mostly unless it becomes clear he is weak - the default is they do not narrate except from a trustworthy person. But if his weakness becomes clear, the general authentication is not accepted merely because they do not narrate except from a trustworthy person. 
Warning: If you find a hadith regarding rulings and find no biography for its narrator, but Ahmed or Malik or their likes who do not narrate except from trustworthy people narrated from him, this hadith is not corrected in

rulings. Al-Dhahabi said: The majority view is that a narrator from whom a group of trustworthy people narrate and who does not bring something denounced (Munkar), his hadith is accepted. His saying: "and who does not bring something denounced," means - and Allah knows best -: he does not stand alone with a ruling. For if he stands alone with a ruling, he has brought something denounced. Thus Al-Dhahabi says in *Al-Muqizah*: The Truthful (Saduq) - who is below Thiqah - if he stands alone with a ruling, sometimes it is accepted and sometimes rejected. This is regarding one who is authenticated, so how about one who is not specifically authenticated? This is an important topic that should be regulated. If they say: "So-and-so does not narrate except from a trustworthy person," the meaning is unless his weakness becomes apparent, i.e., mostly. Then if this "trustworthy person" stands alone with a ruling, this hadith is not relied upon.
• Issue Four: If a group of trustworthy people narrate from a narrator and he does not bring what is denounced, Al-Dhahabi and Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi mentioned that the majority accept him. This is correct as mentioned, but the meaning of "does not bring what is denounced" must be understood, i.e., he does not stand alone with a new ruling. If he stands alone with a new ruling, it is not accepted from a "Saduq", so how about one who is not authenticated but merely narrated from by trustworthy people?
• Issue Five: If it is said regarding a narrator that the people of such-and-such neighborhood narrated from him, or his students narrated from him, and his students are known only as trustworthy, his hadith is accepted according to the most correct scholarly views. As Al-Bukhari - may Allah have mercy on him - did in narrating the hadith of Al-Bariqi; he accepted the narrators of his neighborhood. Similarly, Ibn al-Qayyim and others did regarding the narration of Mu'adh's companions from Mu'adh. He said: Because Mu'adh's companions are trustworthy. He said: If his companions narrate from him and his companions are known only as trustworthy, this is considered authentic according to the most correct scholarly views. 
...And other topics related to the Unknown.
His saying: (THEN INNOVATION: EITHER EXCOMMUNICATING [MUKAFFIR], OR CORRUPTING [MUFASSIQ]. THE FIRST: THE MAJORITY DO NOT ACCEPT ITS AUTHOR. THE SECOND: HE IS ACCEPTED IF HE IS NOT A CALLER [TO IT] ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW, UNLESS HE NARRATES WHAT STRENGTHENS HIS INNOVATION, THEN IT IS REJECTED ACCORDING TO THE CHOSEN VIEW, AND AL-JUZJANI, THE SHEIKH OF AL-NASA'I, STATED THIS): If the innovator is a disbeliever, his narration is not accepted by consensus, as narrated by Al-Nawawi - may Allah have mercy on him. However, it should be known that a narrator may fall into a disbelief-causing act without becoming a disbeliever individually; there is no necessary correlation between falling into Kufr and being a Kafir. Ibn Taymiyyah said as in *Majmu' al-Fatawa*: The Book, the Sunnah, Consensus, and Consideration indicate this. But the point is whoever is proven to be a disbeliever, his narration is not accepted.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
As for the one whose disbelief is not proven by being an innovator, Al-Hafiz detailed regarding him, but he said before this: (OR CORRUPTING), and it was previously mentioned that Fisq (corruption/sinfulness) is not a barrier. His saying: (THE FIRST: THE MAJORITY DO NOT ACCEPT ITS AUTHOR) meaning the excommunicating one. It is said: If it means he committed Kufr [and became a Kafir], then by consensus as narrated by Al-Nawawi. If it means he did not become a Kafir, then if he did not become a Kafir, he is an innovator, and it will be mentioned that it is like a consensus among Hadith scholars to accept the narration of the innovator. 
His saying: (THE SECOND: HE IS ACCEPTED IF HE IS NOT A CALLER [TO IT] ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW, UNLESS HE NARRATES WHAT STRENGTHENS HIS INNOVATION, THEN IT IS REJECTED ACCORDING TO THE CHOSEN VIEW, AND AL-JUZJANI, THE SHEIKH OF AL-NASA'I, STATED THIS): Meaning the one who fell into a corrupting innovation (HE IS ACCEPTED IF HE IS NOT A CALLER...). It should be known that dividing innovations into excommunicating and non-excommunicating is agreed upon by consensus, as narrated by Sheikh Hafiz Hakami in *Ma'arij al-Qabul*, and many scholars established that there are excommunicating and non-excommunicating innovations. If it is said: How is excommunicating innovation distinguished from non-excommunicating? It is said: By looking at the ruling of the action itself apart from the description of innovation. Like invoking saints; this is Kufr without looking at the description of innovation. As for collective Dhikr (remembrance), this is not Kufr without looking at the description of innovation. If looked at with the description of innovation, it becomes an innovation - i.e., collective supplication. Invoking saints, if worshipped thereby, is an excommunicating innovation, because the ruling of the action without the description of innovation is Kufr. 
The most apparent view - and Allah knows best - is that the narration of the innovator is accepted, and it is like a consensus among people of knowledge as narrated by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in his book *Al-Kifayah*. He said: This is the view of Ali bin al-Madini... and he listed a large group of scholars. It is the practice of the authors of the two Sahihs, Imam Al-Bukhari and Muslim. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated with their chains from Qais bin Abi Hazim from Amr bin Al-Aas that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Verily the family of so-and-so are not my allies (Awliya'), my Ally is only Allah..." 'Family of so-and-so' means the family of Abu Talib. Qais bin Abi Hazim, although trustworthy, was accused of Nasb (hatred of Ali), and this hadith strengthens his innovation, yet Al-Bukhari and Muslim accepted the hadith. 
Second Example: Imam Muslim narrated the hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib containing Adi bin Thabit, which is that Ali said: "The Unlettered Prophet covenanted to me that none loves me but a believer and none hates me but a hypocrite." This hadith outwardly strengthens the innovation of Shi'ism, and Adi bin Thabit was an Imam of the Shia and their preacher, yet Muslim narrated
