what strengthens his innovation outwardly, because Qais bin Abi Hazim and Adi bin Thabit are trustworthy, known for truthfulness and do not lie. Had they lied, the Hadith scholars would have exposed them. Since they are truthful (Saduq), scholars accepted these two hadiths. In fact, Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated them; Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated the first hadith, and Muslim narrated the second hadith, even though it strengthens their innovation. This is the apparent view - and Allah knows best - for the reliance is on precision and truthfulness.
His saying: (THEN BAD MEMORY: IF IT IS INHERENT, IT IS THE ANOMALOUS [SHADH] ACCORDING TO ONE OPINION, OR IF IT OCCURRED LATER, IT IS THE MIXED UP [MUKHTALIT]): It was previously mentioned that these detailed classifications are not correct. However, his saying: (IF IT IS INHERENT, IT IS THE ANOMALOUS ACCORDING TO ONE OPINION), it was mentioned that the meaning of Shadh is absolute uniqueness; it may be from a trustworthy person or a weak one. 
His saying: (OR IF IT OCCURRED LATER, IT IS THE MIXED UP): The Mukhtalit (Mixed up) narrator. Attention should be paid to an important topic, which is that mixing (Ikhtilat) and change (Taghayyur) are two types:
• Type One: Non-harmful mixing.
• Type Two: Harmful mixing.
Non-harmful mixing is when a narrator's memory changes a change that does not make him alter hadiths and their chains, or he changes a change that alters hadiths and chains but he did not narrate during his harmful mixing, as his sons and students prevented him... etc. 
As for harmful mixing, it is one who changed a harmful change and narrated during his change. The criterion to distinguish between them: If scholars say: If he narrated early, his early students were precise, unlike his students after that who were not. Or they distinguished between years, saying: Whoever narrated from him before year such-and-such was precise, and after year such-and-such was not... If they mention what indicates defining the time of his precision and lack thereof, and acceptance of his narration and non-acceptance based on his condition, time, and self; this is harmful change and is called Ikhtilat. This is a summary of what Al-Mu'allimi established in his book *Al-Tankil*, which is a precious research worth writing in gold water. Many Hafizs undergo change, and not every change causes the hadith to be rejected. It might be a change that does not harm, though his memory isn't like before. Or it might be a change that harms, which is Ikhtilat. Then, the one who changed a harmful change might not have narrated during his change, so his change does not harm because he did not narrate during it. What harms is one who changed a harmful change and then narrated.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
This topic mentioned by Al-Mu'allimi is extremely precious; because through it, one can practically distinguish between narrators accused of mixing and change. Not everyone accused of mixing is rejected, and not everyone accused of change is rejected. It must be regulated by what was previously mentioned.
His saying: (AND WHENEVER THE ONE WITH BAD MEMORY IS CORROBORATED BY A CONSIDERED NARRATOR, AND LIKEWISE THE VEILED [MASTUR], THE MURSAL, AND THE MUDALLIS: THEIR HADITH BECOMES HASAN NOT BY ITSELF, BUT BY THE TOTALITY): The discussion on this has preceded. If such narrators are corroborated, it indicates they were precise; because the Mastur is unknown in condition, and there is nothing indicating his hadith is error or illusion, so it was left as a precaution. But if corroborated, this doubt is removed. Similarly, the Mursal narrator was left fearing the intermediary might be weak, but if corroborated, the opposite becomes clear. Likewise, the Mudallis is like the Mursal.

text: Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: Then the chain (Isnad): Either it ends at the Prophet - peace be upon him -, explicitly or judgmentally: from his saying, action, or approval. Or to the Companion likewise, and he is: whoever met the Prophet - peace be upon him and his family - believing in him, and died on Islam, even if apostasy intervened according to the more correct view. Or to the Successor (Tabi'i): and he is whoever met the Companion likewise. The first is: The Raised (Marfu'), the second: The Suspended (Mawquf), the third: The Cut (Maqtu'). And whoever is below the Successor is like him. The last two are called: The Effect (Al-Athar). And the Musnad is: The raised narration of a Companion with a chain that is outwardly connected. If its number [of narrators] is few: it either ends at the Prophet - peace be upon him -, or to an Imam of high description like Shu'bah. The first is: Absolute High [Isnad]. The second: Relative. It includes Agreement (Muwafaqah): which is reaching the Sheikh of one of the authors via other than his path. And Substitution (Badal): which is reaching the Sheikh of his Sheikh likewise. And Equality (Musawah): which is the equality of the number of the chain from the narrator to its end, with the chain of one of the authors. And Handshaking (Musafahah): which is equality with the student of that author. Opposing High [Isnad] in its types is: Descent (Nuzul). If the narrator and the one narrating from him share age and meeting, it is Peers (Aqran). If each of them narrates from the other: it is Mudabbaj. If he narrates from someone below him: it is Elders from Youngers (Akabir 'an Asaghir); from it is Fathers from Sons. In its opposite [Sons from Fathers] is abundance; from it is one who narrates from his father from his grandfather. If two share a Sheikh, and the death of one preceded, it is: The Previous and The Later (Sabiq wa Lahiq). If he narrates from two with the same name, and they are not distinguished, then by his specialty with one of them, the Neglected (Muhmal) is clarified.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
IF THE SHEIKH DENIES HIS NARRATION WITH CERTAINTY: IT IS REJECTED, OR WITH PROBABILITY: IT IS ACCEPTED ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW. INCLUDED IN IT IS: "WHOEVER NARRATED AND FORGOT". IF THE NARRATORS AGREE IN THE FORMULAS OF PERFORMANCE, OR OTHER STATES, IT IS THE SERIAL (MUSALSAL).
His saying: (...THE FIRST: THE RAISED [MARFU'], THE SECOND: THE SUSPENDED [MAWQUF], THE THIRD: THE CUT [MAQTU'], AND WHOEVER IS BELOW THE SUCCESSOR IS LIKE HIM. THE LAST TWO ARE CALLED: THE EFFECT [AL-ATHAR]): The summary of the foregoing: What is narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, is Marfu'; what is narrated from the Companion is Mawquf; and what is narrated from the Successor is Maqtu'. Then he divided Marfu' into two types: either explicitly Marfu' or judgmentally Marfu'. This explicit Marfu' and judgmental Marfu' can be from his saying, action, or approval. Explicit Marfu' from his saying is like saying: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Actions are but by intentions." Or his action: The Prophet, peace be upon him, when he prostrated, did not spread his arms... etc., hadiths mentioning his action, peace be upon him. Or his approval: that he sees something and approves them on it; this is the explicit. The Judgmental (Hukmi): is what indicates that but is not explicit, like a Companion saying: "It is from the Sunnah such-and-such" or "Two dead things and two bloods were made lawful for us." This is judgmentally Marfu' from his saying, peace be upon him. Similarly, if a Companion says: "It is from the Sunnah to do such-and-such," this is also judgmentally Marfu'. His approval [judgmentally] is that something is done in his time and the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not see it, like Jabir's saying: "We used to practice coitus interruptus while the Quran was being revealed." This is from his judgmental approval. So Marfu' can be judgmental or explicit, and can be verbal, active, or approval.
As for Mawquf, it is not divided into explicit and judgmental. Mawquf is the saying of the Companion, his action, or his approval. Similarly, Maqtu', and Maqtu' is for those below the Successor; it is the saying, action, and approval of the Successor. It can be for those below him like the Successor of the Successor, so what is said about those below the Successor is like what is said about the Successor. 
It should be known that some early scholars used "Maqtu'" for "Munqati'" (disconnected), as Al-Bardiji did, and some used "Munqati'" meaning "Maqtu'", as Imam Al-Shafi'i did.

text:
This depends on the practice of scholars, their terminologies, and actions. Therefore, a student of knowledge should be well-read and read extensively to know the incidental terminologies of scholars, either by looking into books of Terminology or commentaries on Hadith, and so on as will be mentioned - Allah willing.
His saying: (THE LAST TWO ARE CALLED: THE EFFECT [AL-ATHAR]): The last two: meaning the Mawquf and Maqtu'. Al-Nawawi - may Allah have mercy on him - mentioned that Hadith scholars do not differentiate between Hadith and Athar. He said: As for the Khurasanis, they differentiate between them, making the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him, "Hadith" and the saying of those below him "Athar". This was mentioned in the beginning of the explanation. The correct view is that all are called Athar, and using "Hadith" for what is raised to the Prophet, peace be upon him, became famous.
His saying: (AND THE MUSNAD IS: THE RAISED NARRATION OF A COMPANION WITH A CHAIN THAT IS OUTWARDLY CONNECTED): So you say: This is a Musnad hadith. His saying: (WITH A CHAIN THAT IS OUTWARDLY CONNECTED) means the hadith might be Mudallas (concealed) or Mursal Khafi (hidden disconnected). In a similar way, Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim defined it in his book *Ma'rifat Ulum al-Hadith*. The more correct view - and Allah knows best - is that scholars include in "Masanid" even hadiths that are clearly and obviously Mursal, as is evident by looking at the Musnad of Imam Ahmed - may Allah have mercy on him. The matter in this is simple - Allah willing. The meaning of Musnad: whatever is attributed to the Prophet, peace be upon him, even if it is Mursal. The matter is easy, praise be to Allah.
His saying: (IF ITS NUMBER [OF NARRATORS] IS FEW: IT EITHER ENDS AT THE PROPHET - PEACE BE UPON HIM -, OR TO AN IMAM OF HIGH DESCRIPTION LIKE SHU'BAH. THE FIRST IS: ABSOLUTE HIGH [ISNAD]. THE SECOND: RELATIVE): It should be known that there is what is called High (Ali) and Low (Nazil). If the narrators between the author and the Prophet, peace be upon him, are few, it is called a High Hadith. If the narrators are many, it is called a Low Hadith. In Bukhari there are Thulathiyat (chains with three narrators), so this is considered a High Hadith. Hadith scholars love the High Chain, so much that when Ibn Ma'in was asked: What do you desire? He said: I desire a high chain and an empty house. Ibn al-Salah mentioned this in his Introduction. The benefit of the High Chain is that since the number of narrators is few, it becomes easier to reach a conclusion on the authenticity or weakness of the hadith, unlike if the chain is Low, as it requires greater effort, and there is a probability of an unnoticed error... etc.

text:
Then he divided Highness into two types: Absolute Highness, which is to the Prophet, peace be upon him, as mentioned previously. Or Relative Highness, meaning between the author and Shu'bah, for example, there are two [narrators], while usually there would be three for someone like him. This is called: Relative Highness.
His saying: (IT INCLUDES AGREEMENT [MUWAFAQAH]: WHICH IS REACHING THE SHEIKH OF ONE OF THE AUTHORS VIA OTHER THAN HIS PATH. AND SUBSTITUTION [BADAL]: WHICH IS REACHING THE SHEIKH OF HIS SHEIKH LIKEWISE): It should be known that the division is as follows: Muwafaqah and Badal are counterparts, and Musawah and Musafahah are counterparts. The meaning of Muwafaqah: Someone narrates a hadith and reaches the Sheikh of the author, like the Sheikh of Al-Bukhari for example, via a path other than Al-Bukhari's. This is called Muwafaqah. Or reaching the Sheikh of Al-Bukhari's Sheikh, which is called Badal. These are counterparts.
His saying: (AND EQUALITY [MUSAWAH]: WHICH IS THE EQUALITY OF THE NUMBER OF THE CHAIN FROM THE NARRATOR TO ITS END, WITH THE CHAIN OF ONE OF THE AUTHORS. AND HANDSHAKING [MUSAFAHAH]: WHICH IS EQUALITY WITH THE STUDENT OF THAT AUTHOR): If a narrator narrates a hadith and between him and the Prophet, peace be upon him, is the same number as between Al-Bukhari and the Prophet, peace be upon him, it is called Musawah. Or if between him and the Prophet, peace be upon him, is the same number as between Al-Bukhari's student and the Prophet, peace be upon him, it is called Musafahah. These are branches of High and Low Hadith. 
His saying: (OPPOSING HIGH [ISNAD] IN ITS TYPES IS: DESCENT [NUZUL]): Because Descent is the counterpart of Highness and opposes it.
His saying: (IF THE NARRATOR AND THE ONE NARRATING FROM HIM SHARE AGE AND MEETING, IT IS PEERS [AQRAN]. IF EACH OF THEM NARRATES FROM THE OTHER: IT IS MUDABBAJ): So these two things are required for Peers: Age and Meeting. If they are equal in age and meeting, they are Peers. If the two peers narrate from each other, it is called Mudabbaj.
His saying: (IF HE NARRATES FROM SOMEONE BELOW HIM: IT IS ELDERS FROM YOUNGERS [AKABIR 'AN ASAGHIR], FROM IT IS FATHERS FROM SONS. IN ITS OPPOSITE [SONS FROM FATHERS] IS ABUNDANCE; FROM IT IS ONE WHO NARRATES FROM HIS FATHER FROM HIS GRANDFATHER): The default is the son narrating from his father. If reversed and the father narrates from his son, he said: It is Elders from Youngers... His saying: (IN ITS OPPOSITE IS ABUNDANCE) meaning narration of sons from fathers. From it is one who narrated from his father from his grandfather. This is a famous chain in many narrators. Most famous are the narration of: Bahz bin Hakim from his father from his grandfather, and the narration of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather. The narration of Bahz bin Hakim from his father from his grandfather is more authentic than the narration of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather. The default in the narration of Bahz bin Hakim from

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
his father from his grandfather is that it is accepted. As for what Amr bin Shu'aib stands alone in narrating from his father from his grandfather, the default is that it is not accepted, but it is valid for witnesses (Shawahid) and corroborations (Mutaba'at), but it is not valid independently to establish a legal ruling. Therefore, Hadith scholars use it as proof (Yahtajjun bihi), and the phrase "Yahtajjun" sometimes means: they accept it in witnesses and corroborations, i.e., they use it as proof along with others, not by itself. Therefore, Abu Ubayd said in his book *Al-Amwal* regarding the hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather on Zakat of jewelry: Scholars continue to speak about it, past and present. Thus, if Amr bin Shu'aib stands alone from his father from his grandfather with a hadith, it is not strong enough to independently establish a legal ruling. Similarly, Muhammad bin Ishaq, the author of *Al-Siyar wa Al-Maghazi*. Imam Ahmed and Al-Dhahabi mentioned that what he stands alone in is not accepted, because he has errors. Among them is the hadith of Sahl bin Hunaif narrated by Abu Dawood and others that Madhiy is sprinkled [with water], meaning the impurity of Madhiy is lightened so sprinkling is sufficient and washing is not required. Muhammad bin Ishaq, the author of *Al-Siyar wa Al-Maghazi*, stood alone in this, so it is not accepted. It was previously mentioned that Hadith scholars deem uniqueness (Tafarrud) a defect. Among the hadiths Muhammad bin Ishaq stood alone with: The hadith of Ubada bin Samit in Imam Ahmed and others: "Perhaps you recite behind your Imam?" We said: Yes. He said: "Do not do so except with Fatihat al-Kitab (The Opening of the Book), for there is no prayer for one who does not recite it." This has more than one defect, including the uniqueness of Muhammad bin Ishaq, and that he contradicted Al-Zuhri, among other defects.
His saying: (IF TWO SHARE A SHEIKH, AND THE DEATH OF ONE PRECEDED, IT IS: THE PREVIOUS AND THE LATER [SABIQ WA LAHIQ]): If two narrate, even if they differ in age, from one Sheikh, and one dies before the other, it is called: The Previous and The Later.
His saying: (IF HE NARRATES FROM TWO WITH THE SAME NAME, AND THEY ARE NOT DISTINGUISHED, THEN BY HIS SPECIALTY WITH ONE OF THEM, THE NEGLECTED [MUHMAL] IS CLARIFIED): It was previously mentioned that the Neglected is one whose name is mentioned alone, saying: Muhammad, or Sufyan, or Hammad. It could be Hammad bin Zaid or Hammad bin Salamah. In Sufyan, it could be Ibn Uyainah or Al-Thawri. So how to distinguish between them? One looks at who narrated from him; is he a student who narrates frequently from one of them or not? Suppose he narrates frequently from Ibn Uyainah, it is said: This Neglected one is Ibn Uyainah.
His saying: (IF THE SHEIKH DENIES HIS NARRATION WITH CERTAINTY: IT IS REJECTED, OR WITH PROBABILITY: IT IS ACCEPTED ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW. INCLUDED IN IT IS: "WHOEVER NARRATED AND FORGOT"): The Sheikh's denial of the hadith narrated by the student has three states:

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
• State One: That he belies him. If he belies him, his hadith is rejected and not accepted by consensus, as narrated by Al-Nawawi - may Allah have mercy on him.
• State Two: That he asserts his error. The majority accept it as narrated by Ibn Hajar, and the practice of Al-Bukhari and Muslim indicates this.
• State Three: That he does not assert his error but hesitates. This is accepted all the more, and Ibn Hajar narrated consensus on it, and Al-Sakhawi quoted it.
His saying: (IF THE NARRATORS AGREE IN THE FORMULAS OF PERFORMANCE, OR OTHER STATES, IT IS THE SERIAL [MUSALSAL]): The Musalsal is when a student narrates from his Sheikh by anything that follows a sequence. Sometimes by formula, they all say: "I heard" (Sami'tu). Sometimes by action, like extending his hand or smiling. Sometimes he says: "I love you for the sake of Allah." So what accompanies the narration and the Sheikh narrates to his student, and the student to his student... etc., is called Musalsal. It may be from the beginning of the chain to its end, or in part of the chain. Most Musalsals are weak and not authentic as Al-Dhahabi said. The Musalsal has no benefit except that it indicates hearing (Sama'). So if it is assumed he is a Mudallis, his hadith is accepted because it indicates hearing, as Ibn al-Salah and others mentioned.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: AND FORMULAS OF PERFORMANCE: 'I HEARD' (SAMI'TU) AND 'HE TOLD ME' (HADDATHANI); THEN 'HE INFORMED ME' (AKHBARANI) AND 'I READ TO HIM' (QARA'TU 'ALAYH); THEN 'IT WAS READ TO HIM WHILE I LISTENED'; THEN 'HE INFORMED ME' (ANBA'ANI); THEN 'HE HANDED ME' (NAWALANI); THEN 'HE SPOKE TO ME' (SHAFAHANI); THEN 'HE WROTE TO ME' (KATABA ILAYYA); THEN 'FROM' (AN), AND THE LIKE. THE FIRST TWO: FOR WHOEVER HEARD ALONE FROM THE SHEIKH'S WORDING. IF HE WAS WITH OTHERS, THEN 'WITH OTHERS' [HE TOLD US]. THE FIRST IS THE MOST EXPLICIT AND HIGHEST IN DICTATION. THE THIRD AND FOURTH: FOR WHOEVER READ HIMSELF. IF WITH OTHERS: THEN LIKE THE FIFTH. AND 'INBA'' (INFORMING) MEANS 'IKHBAR' (INFORMING), EXCEPT IN THE USAGE OF LATE SCHOLARS, IT IS FOR PERMISSION (IJAZAH) LIKE 'AN' (FROM). AND THE 'AN'ANAH' OF A CONTEMPORARY IS CONSTRUED AS HEARING EXCEPT FROM A MUDALLIS. IT IS SAID: PROOF OF THEIR MEETING IS A CONDITION - EVEN IF ONCE - AND THIS IS THE CHOSEN VIEW. THEY APPLIED 'MUSHAFAHAH' (ORAL TRANSMISSION) TO SPOKEN PERMISSION, AND 'MUKATABAH' (CORRESPONDENCE) TO WRITTEN PERMISSION. THEY STIPULATED FOR THE VALIDITY OF 'MUNAWALAH' (HANDING OVER) ITS ASSOCIATION WITH PERMISSION TO NARRATE, AND IT IS THE HIGHEST TYPE OF PERMISSION. LIKEWISE, THEY STIPULATED PERMISSION IN 'WIJADAH' (FINDING), 'WASIYYAH' (BEQUEST) OF A BOOK, AND 'I'LAM' (INFORMING). OTHERWISE, THERE IS NO CONSIDERATION FOR IT, LIKE GENERAL PERMISSION, AND FOR THE UNKNOWN, AND FOR THE NON-EXISTENT, ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW IN ALL THAT. THEN THE NARRATORS: IF THEIR NAMES AGREE, AND THEIR FATHERS' NAMES AND UPWARDS, BUT THEIR PERSONS DIFFER: IT IS THE AGREED AND SEPARATED (MUTTAFIQ WA MUFTARIQ). IF THE NAMES AGREE IN WRITING BUT DIFFER IN PRONUNCIATION: IT IS THE CONSONANT AND DISSONANT (MU'TALIF WA MUKHTALIF). IF THE NAMES AGREE AND FATHERS DIFFER, OR VICE VERSA: IT IS THE RESEMBLING (MUTASHABIH). LIKEWISE IF AGREEMENT OCCURS IN THE NAME AND FATHER'S NAME, AND DIFFERENCE IN LINEAGE. TYPES ARE COMPOSED OF IT AND WHAT PRECEDED IT: AMONG THEM IS THAT AGREEMENT OR RESEMBLANCE OCCURS EXCEPT IN A LETTER OR TWO, OR BY ADVANCING AND DELAYING OR THE LIKE. 
His saying: (AND FORMULAS OF PERFORMANCE: 'I HEARD' AND 'HE TOLD ME'; THEN 'HE INFORMED ME' AND 'I READ TO HIM'; THEN 'IT WAS READ TO HIM WHILE I LISTENED'; THEN 'HE INFORMED ME'; THEN 'HE HANDED ME'; THEN 'HE SPOKE TO ME'; THEN 'HE WROTE TO ME'; THEN 'FROM', AND THE LIKE. THE FIRST TWO: FOR WHOEVER HEARD ALONE FROM THE SHEIKH'S WORDING. IF HE WAS WITH OTHERS, THEN 'WITH OTHERS'): The first two means: Sami'tu and Haddathani. His saying: (IF HE WAS WITH OTHERS) meaning Sami'na and Haddathana. His saying: (THE FIRST IS THE MOST EXPLICIT AND HIGHEST IN DICTATION) is the saying: Sami'tu (I heard).

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
His saying: (AND 'INBA'' (INFORMING) MEANS 'IKHBAR' (INFORMING), EXCEPT IN THE USAGE OF LATE SCHOLARS, IT IS FOR PERMISSION (IJAZAH) LIKE 'AN' (FROM)): The origin is that there is no difference between saying: Sami'tu, Haddathani, or Sami'na, Haddathana, or Akhbarani or Akhbarana. The origin is there is no difference between them. Yahya bin Sa'id explicitly stated this as narrated by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in his book *Al-Kifayah*. There is no difference between Sami'tu, Sami'na, Haddathani, Haddathana, Akhbarani, Akhbarana. Imam Ahmed - may Allah have mercy on him - mentioned something similar, unless it becomes clear that a scholar has a specific terminology; otherwise, the default is no difference between these formulas.
His saying: (AND THE 'AN'ANAH' OF A CONTEMPORARY IS CONSTRUED AS HEARING EXCEPT FROM A MUDALLIS. IT IS SAID: PROOF OF THEIR MEETING IS A CONDITION - EVEN IF ONCE - AND THIS IS THE CHOSEN VIEW): Scholars disputed regarding the 'An'anah' of a contemporary whose meeting and hearing from his Sheikh is not proven. Two men were contemporaries and it was possible for the student to hear from his Sheikh or for one to hear from the other, but it did not come in any path that one heard from the other, rather he narrated with a formula allowing for hearing; this is called 'An'anah of the Contemporary'. Imam Muslim - may Allah have mercy on him - went in his Introduction to the view that 'An'anah' of a contemporary is valid and accepted. Imam Al-Bukhari went to the view that 'An'anah' of a contemporary is not accepted until meeting (Liqa') is proven. Al-Bukhari's view is more correct; in fact, Ibn Rajab narrated it as consensus among Hadith scholars before Imam Muslim, as he narrated in the explanation of *Al-Arba'in* and in the explanation of *Al-Ilal*. Hadith scholars are unanimous on Al-Bukhari's condition, that the 'An'anah' of a contemporary is not accepted until his meeting with him is proven even once, either by explicitly declaring hearing or something similar. This is confirmed by the fact that even if a narrator is free from Tadlis (obfuscation), he might not be free from Hidden Irsal (sending). This cannot be regulated except by proving meeting. If meeting is proven even once and he is not described as a Mudallis, the default is his narration is accepted. Because it was previously mentioned that Tadlis applies to known Tadlis and Hidden Irsal, but it might not apply to Hidden Irsal, and he is not called a Mudallis even if he has Hidden Irsal in the sense mentioned by Hafiz Ibn Hajar as previously explained. And Tadlis might be applied to one who has Hidden Irsal. So the point is Al-Bukhari's condition is more correct, and this is what early Hadith scholars before Imam Muslim were upon. Abu Hatim said: Agreement of Hadith scholars is proof. This is strengthened by the fact that it blocks the door for those of Hidden Irsal, as Ibn Hajar explained in *Al-Nukat ala Ibn al-Salah*. I draw attention to issues:

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
• Issue One: If a Mudallis explicitly declares hearing, his hadith is accepted by consensus. Ibn Abd al-Barr narrated the consensus, and the words of early scholars indicate it.
• Issue Two: A narrator might say in a hadith: "So-and-so told us" or "So-and-so told me" or "So-and-so informed me"... etc., and it is a mistake by him, as Imam Ahmed and others explained regarding a group of narrators. Ibn Rajab quoted some of that in the explanation of *Al-Ilal*. Therefore, if Hadith scholars say: His saying "Haddathana" or "Sami'tu" is a mistake, their word is final.
• Issue Three: A narrator's hearing from another narrator might not be proven, but his hadith is accepted due to an indicator (Qarinah). It was previously mentioned that what is proven to be disconnected is accepted [in certain contexts or if supported], so how about what is not so regarding unproven meeting? Thus, accepting Imam Muslim's condition does not necessitate that he built his Sahih on it, because he takes precaution in the Sahih, so he does not include except what is not like that [disconnected] or what is like that but indicators pointed to its acceptance. Therefore, when Ibn Rajab preferred this view - which is Al-Bukhari's condition - he said: And a hadith where meeting is not proven might be accepted, meaning by indicators as previously explained.
His saying: (THEY APPLIED 'MUSHAFAHAH' (ORAL TRANSMISSION) TO SPOKEN PERMISSION, AND 'MUKATABAH' (CORRESPONDENCE) TO WRITTEN PERMISSION): Mushafahah: Meaning so-and-so spoke to me. And Spoken: Meaning saying "I permitted you" or "I permitted those present." Mukatabah: He wrote a permission to so-and-so, so he says "He corresponded with me."
His saying: (THEY STIPULATED FOR THE VALIDITY OF 'MUNAWALAH' (HANDING OVER) ITS ASSOCIATION WITH PERMISSION TO NARRATE, AND IT IS THE HIGHEST TYPE OF PERMISSION): If a Sheikh hands his books to his student but does not permit him to narrate, they said: The student's narration from his Sheikh's books which he handed to him is not considered if he did not permit him. This is the majority view. There is a second view in the issue: That it is considered, and this is the default, unless it becomes clear by an indicator that there is something in the books; otherwise, the default is it is considered - and Allah knows best. That is like Wijadah (finding). Muslim narrated from the hadith of Makhramah bin Bukayr from his father, and Makhramah bin Bukayr found his father's books and narrated from them without permission from his father, because he found them after his father's death. Imam Muslim accepted it, and narrated several hadiths from that in Sahih Muslim, including: What Muslim narrated from the hadith of Aisha: "There is no day on which Allah frees servants more than the Day of Arafah, and indeed He draws near to the servants..." This is from the narration of Makhramah bin Bukayr from his father. Muslim placed it in the principles (Usul) and not

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
in the witnesses (Mushahadat) and followers (Tawabi'), but rather placed it in the principles and relied on it due to his validation of narration by Wijadah, along with other hadiths. Therefore, the more correct view - and Allah knows best - is the second view, that if he hands to his student, or [the student] finds his Sheikh's books... etc., the default is it is valid to narrate from them unless it becomes clear there is something [wrong] in the books.
His saying: (LIKEWISE, THEY STIPULATED PERMISSION IN 'WIJADAH', 'WASIYYAH' OF A BOOK, AND 'I'LAM', OTHERWISE THERE IS NO CONSIDERATION FOR IT, LIKE GENERAL PERMISSION, AND FOR THE UNKNOWN, AND FOR THE NON-EXISTENT, ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW IN ALL THAT): Stipulating permission in Wijadah is the majority view; otherwise, there is a second view in the issue that permission is not a condition, and it is the correct view as previously mentioned. Examples of narrators: Makhramah bin Bukayr from his father. His saying: (AND 'WASIYYAH' OF A BOOK): That he bequeaths his books upon his death to his son or his student so-and-so, but does not permit him to narrate. Or he bequeaths his books upon his travel to his student so-and-so, but does not permit him to narrate. According to the correct view, narration is valid for him even without permission. His saying: (AND IN 'I'LAM', OTHERWISE THERE IS NO CONSIDERATION FOR IT): Meaning it is known he has books, so he says to one of his students: "I have books," and informs him of his books, but did not permit him to narrate. His student found these books; he has the right to narrate from these books. Clearer than this is if the Sheikh informs his student that he narrates from Sheikh so-and-so and that he heard from so-and-so; his informing him is considered. Similarly in what was mentioned before, if he informs him he has books from so-and-so and did not permit him to narrate from him, it is also considered. His saying: (OTHERWISE THERE IS NO CONSIDERATION FOR IT) meaning without permission; this is the majority view and the correct view is opposite as mentioned. His saying: (OTHERWISE THERE IS NO CONSIDERATION FOR IT) meaning like that which is not considered (LIKE GENERAL PERMISSION, AND FOR THE UNKNOWN, AND FOR THE NON-EXISTENT, ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW IN ALL THAT). In General Permission he says: "I permitted the people of Medina" or "I permitted Muslims generally." This is not considered. He may also permit an unknown person, saying: "I permitted a man," and this man is unknown not recognized. Or he says: "I permitted Muhammad." This is Neglected (Muhmal) and is a type of Unknown. As for the Non-existent, like saying: "I permitted the children of so-and-so if they are born." And they do not exist. His saying: (ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW IN ALL THAT): Regarding Ijazah (Permission), the matter is as Al-Hafiz mentioned. As for what preceded regarding Wasiyyah, Munawalah, Wijadah... etc., the correct view is the Sheikh's permission is not stipulated - and Allah knows best. 
Then I warn against exaggeration in Ijazat (Licenses). Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani used to condemn these licenses that spread in these later times. Also, the great scholar and Hafiz Sheikh Abdullah Al-Duwaish - may Allah have mercy on him - used to condemn these licenses and say: There is no benefit in them. And he spoke the truth - may Allah have mercy on him. Many students are eager for these licenses and may travel East

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
and West and waste their time to obtain an Ijazah from so-and-so. Such things have absolutely no benefit. In fact, sometimes you meet a Sheikh and he says: "I permitted you with all my narrations," while perhaps you can barely read a line. So the student becomes afflicted with vanity and might exaggerate this Ijazah, and might get tired. These Ijazat might harm the student by causing vanity, or harm him by expending great effort to obtain them, wasting his time. They might not harm him but they are of no benefit. Some say: This is preservation of Isnad (Chain of Transmission) which is a characteristic of this Ummah... However, it should be known that Isnad is desired for other than itself, not for itself; it is desired for preserving the Prophetic Hadith, so it is not desired for itself. One should not exaggerate in these Ijazat nor waste times nor squander them in acquiring them.
His saying: (THEN THE NARRATORS: IF THEIR NAMES AGREE, AND THEIR FATHERS' NAMES AND UPWARDS, BUT THEIR PERSONS DIFFER: IT IS THE AGREED AND SEPARATED [MUTTAFIQ WA MUFTARIQ], IF THE NAMES AGREE IN WRITING BUT DIFFER IN PRONUNCIATION: IT IS THE CONSONANT AND DISSONANT [MU'TALIF WA MUKHTALIF]): Agreed and Separated is broader than what Al-Hafiz mentioned. The meaning of Agreed and Separated: Similarity occurring in narrators until it is thought they are one, while they are two persons. They might agree in Kunyas (nicknames), in Lineage, in Name and Father's Name and Lineage, or in Name and Father's Name. The unifying factor is that they are thought to be one narrator, while in reality, they are two or more narrators. 
His saying: (IF THE NAMES AGREE IN WRITING BUT DIFFER IN PRONUNCIATION: IT IS THE CONSONANT AND DISSONANT [MU'TALIF WA MUKHTALIF]): Like Muhammad bin 'Aqil, as Al-Hafiz - may Allah have mercy on him - explained in his commentary *Nuzhat al-Nazar*, saying: Like Muhammad bin 'Aqil - with Fatha on 'Ayn - and Muhammad bin 'Uqil - with Damma. The first is Naysaburi, the second Faryabi. Both are famous and their class (Tabaqah) is close.
His saying: (IF THE NAMES AGREE AND FATHERS DIFFER, OR VICE VERSA: IT IS THE RESEMBLING [MUTASHABIH]): The Resembling combines the Agreed and Separated with the Consonant and Dissonant; meaning there is agreement in things and difference in things, so it is called Resembling.
His saying: (LIKEWISE IF AGREEMENT OCCURS IN THE NAME AND FATHER'S NAME, AND DIFFERENCE IN LINEAGE. TYPES ARE COMPOSED OF IT AND WHAT PRECEDED IT: AMONG THEM IS THAT AGREEMENT OR RESEMBLANCE OCCURS EXCEPT IN A LETTER OR TWO, OR BY ADVANCING AND DELAYING OR THE LIKE): His saying: (EXCEPT IN A LETTER OR TWO) like: Muhammad bin Sayyar and Muhammad bin Sinan. His saying: (OR BY ADVANCING AND DELAYING) like: Al-Aswad bin Yazid and Yazid bin Al-Aswad, and so on.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text: Scholars wrote works on this so that narrators would not be confused with one another, thinking a trustworthy one is weak or a weak one is trustworthy.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: CONCLUSION. AND IT IS IMPORTANT: TO KNOW THE LAYERS (TABAQAT) OF NARRATORS, THEIR BIRTHS, DEATHS, LANDS, AND CONDITIONS: REGARDING MODIFICATION (TA'DIL), WOUNDING (JARH), AND IGNORANCE (JAHALAH). AND RANKS OF WOUNDING: THE WORST IS: DESCRIPTION WITH 'AF'AL' (SUPERLATIVE), LIKE 'AKDHAB AL-NAS' (MOST LYING OF PEOPLE), THEN 'DAJJAL' (IMPOSTOR), OR 'WADDA' (FABRICATOR), OR 'KADHDHAB' (LIAR). AND THE EASIEST IS: 'LAYYIN' (SOFT/PLIABLE), OR 'SAYYI' AL-HIFZ' (BAD MEMORY), OR 'FIHI MAQAL' (IN HIM IS SPEECH). AND RANKS OF MODIFICATION: THE HIGHEST IS: DESCRIPTION WITH 'AF'AL' (SUPERLATIVE): LIKE 'AWTHAQ AL-NAS' (MOST TRUSTWORTHY OF PEOPLE), THEN WHAT IS EMPHASIZED WITH AN ATTRIBUTE OR TWO, LIKE 'THIQAH THIQAH' (TRUSTWORTHY TRUSTWORTHY), OR 'THIQAH HAFIZ' (TRUSTWORTHY MEMORIZER). AND THE LOWEST IS: WHAT INDICATES NEARNESS TO THE EASIEST WOUNDING, LIKE: 'SHEIKH'. AND VOUCHING (TAZKIYAH) IS ACCEPTED FROM ONE WHO KNOWS ITS CAUSES, EVEN FROM ONE PERSON, ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW. AND WOUNDING TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER MODIFICATION IF IT IS ISSUED EXPLAINED BY ONE WHO KNOWS ITS CAUSES. IF IT IS DEVOID OF MODIFICATION: IT IS ACCEPTED GENERALLY, ACCORDING TO THE CHOSEN VIEW. 
His saying: (CONCLUSION: AND IT IS IMPORTANT TO KNOW THE LAYERS OF NARRATORS, THEIR BIRTHS, DEATHS, LANDS, AND CONDITIONS: REGARDING MODIFICATION, WOUNDING, AND IGNORANCE): As for the layers of narrators, it should be known that there is no specific criterion for narrator layers. Rather, they are those who share something. Some scholars wrote and made everyone who gathered in ten years a layer, like the practice of Al-Dhahabi in *Tarikh al-Islam*. Others made a generation a layer, like Ibn Hibban in his book *Al-Thiqat* and Al-Dhahabi in *Tarikh al-Islam*. Others made those who gathered in forty years a layer, as Ibn Kathir quoted in his book *Mukhtasar Ulum al-Hadith* from some of them. So, it has no specific criterion. The goal of layers is to distinguish narrators, because two narrators might share one name, so this one is in a layer and that one in another layer, so you find they are two narrators. This was needed greatly before. But for us, after the existence of these indexed books arranged wonderfully alphabetically, then the electronic libraries came, it has become much easier, so we don't need this much, praise be to Allah. His saying: (AND THEIR BIRTHS AND DEATHS AND LANDS...) this is to distinguish narrators from one another. I emphasize that after the existence of these facilities and printing books indexed alphabetically, then the electronic libraries came, it became much easier.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
His saying: (REGARDING MODIFICATION, WOUNDING, AND IGNORANCE): Narrator modification, wounding, and ignorance are known by referring to biographical books, and it has been facilitated, praise be to Allah, as mentioned. 
His saying: (AND RANKS OF WOUNDING): The default in this topic is that it is linguistic. Hadith scholars do not have a consistent terminology. Meaning if they say: "Thiqah Thiqah" (Trustworthy Trustworthy), linguistically this is higher than saying: "Thiqah". And their saying: "Awthaq al-Nas" (Most Trustworthy of People), linguistically this is a higher degree than saying: "Thiqah". So the default in this topic is that it is linguistic, unless it becomes clear that Hadith scholars have a terminology, like saying: "Sheikh". For "Sheikh" is the lowest rank of the trustworthy as Abu Hatim explained in his book *Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil*, or that Hadith scholars have a specific terminology in some words. But that they have a general terminology in all words covering all Hadith scholars, this is not known unless some of them explicitly stated things over others. 
His saying: (AND RANKS OF MODIFICATION: THE HIGHEST IS: DESCRIPTION WITH 'AF'AL' (SUPERLATIVE): LIKE 'AWTHAQ AL-NAS', THEN WHAT IS EMPHASIZED WITH AN ATTRIBUTE OR TWO, LIKE 'THIQAH THIQAH', OR 'THIQAH HAFIZ'. AND THE LOWEST IS: WHAT INDICATES NEARNESS TO THE EASIEST WOUNDING, LIKE: 'SHEIKH'): So I emphasize that the default in these topics is that they are linguistic topics unless it becomes clear there is a special terminology. After this, I draw attention to matters: 
Matter One: If we want to accept a scholar's statement, we must know the proven chain to him. A scholar might say something about another scholar but the chain to him is not proven, as came from Ibn Abbas that he called Ikrimah a liar; this chain is not authentic as Ibn Rajab explained in the explanation of *Al-Ilal* and Ibn Hajar in *Hady al-Sari*. This is needed during severe contradiction. But if their words concur on weakening or authentication, such [verification] is not needed. Also, some books' authors guaranteed the authenticity of the chain [to the critic], like Al-Mizzi in his book *Tahdhib al-Kamal* and Ibn Hajar in *Tahdhib al-Tahdhib* as Al-Mu'allimi - may Allah have mercy on him - explained. 
Matter Two: One should scrutinize when scholars' statements conflict regarding a term different from the scholars' description by way of answer to a question. Sometimes it might be a question and the answer was such. Or it might be a comparison between two narrators so he answered with this. So scrutiny is needed in such cases. He might be severe in stating his weakness because he was compared to a great trustworthy man, and other meanings. So if conflict occurs, one must scrutinize

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
the method of questioning. Al-Mu'allimi - may Allah have mercy on him - pointed to this meaning in his book *Al-Tankil* while answering some problems raised by the Jahmi Al-Kawthari. 
Matter Three: Some scholars have special terminologies that must be noted. Like Ibn Ma'in, for example, if he says: "Laysa bi-shay'" (He is nothing), he intends he is weak OR he intends he has few narrations, as Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi explained in his book *Bayan al-Wahm wa al-Iham*. Some express with two terms and the difference is not noticed, like saying regarding a narrator: "Laysa bi-al-Qawi" (Not the strong one) and "Laysa Qawiyyan" (Not strong). Their saying "Laysa bi-Qawi" is weaker than "Laysa Qawiyyan". The reference for this is the language, and Al-Mu'allimi - may Allah have mercy on him - explained this in his book *Al-Tankil*. So the special terminologies of scholars must be known as mentioned about Ibn Ma'in. 
Matter Four: Some scholars are interested in this field - Jarh and Ta'dil - like Yahya bin Ma'in. Therefore, if a Sheikh sees him, he might beautify himself with the best hadith, so Yahya is deceived by him. Thus, if you see the words of scholars concurring on a meaning except Yahya bin Ma'in, it might be of this nature, as Al-Mu'allimi explained in his book *Al-Tankil*. 
Matter Five: Scholars vary in their strictness. Some scholars are strict in wounding like Abu Hatim, Ibn Kharash, and Yahya bin Sa'id. Some are moderate like Ibn Mahdi and Imam Ahmed. Some are lax as mentioned like Ibn Hibban and Al-Ijli regarding Successors. So the layers of scholars and degrees of scholars in laxity and strictness must be known. This helps during conflict, for the man's method of laxity or strictness or moderation has an effect on him. Al-Dhahabi mentioned this in his book *Al-Muqizah*. If the statement of a strict one conflicts with a moderate one, the moderate one is prioritized, and so on. Some scholars are strict in one thing but not another, like Ibn Hibban; he is severe in wounding, such that he is destructive (Khassaf) in wounding; if he finds the man's illusions he destroys him. Conversely, he is lax in authenticating unknown narrators. So knowing the method and terminology of scholars is important. This is known by extensive reading. What helps is reading extensively in scholars' books and Terminology books. Among the most useful is Al-Sakhawi's book *Fath al-Mughith* because it is distinguished by many quotations, and the book *Al-Nukat ala Muqaddimat Ibn al-Salah* by Hafiz Ibn Hajar, for it is distinguished by quotations and abundant criticism. Reading Ibn Rajab's explanation of *Al-Ilal*, for it has precious benefits. Reading *Bayan al-Wahm wa al-Iham* by Ibn al-Qattan al-Fasi, for it has very important scattered benefits. Reading the two Series (*Silsilahs*) and *Irwa' al-Ghalil* and the detailed graduation (Takhrij)

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
of Sunan Abi Dawood by Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani, for it contains great treasures. Reading all available books of scholars and extracting and collecting these benefits. Reading the book *Tali'at al-Tankil* and *Al-Tankil* by the scholar Al-Mu'allimi, and Al-Mu'allimi's footnotes on *Al-Fawa'id al-Majmu'ah*, and Al-Mu'allimi's refutation of Abu Rayyah, and other such useful books, for they contain precious and scattered benefits. Therefore, by extensive reading, the student can gather scattered points and benefits. 
His saying: (AND VOUCHING [TAZKIYAH] IS ACCEPTED FROM ONE WHO KNOWS ITS CAUSES, EVEN FROM ONE PERSON, ACCORDING TO THE MORE CORRECT VIEW): If a scholar who knows the causes of modification vouches for and modifies someone, even if only one, it is accepted, because he is trustworthy and knowledgeable, so his word is accepted. The word of one person is accepted regarding the Unknown narrator to modify or wound him, because this Unknown has no modification or wounding; he is devoid of modification and wounding. So if a trustworthy scholar knowing the causes of wounding authenticates or wounds him, his word is accepted. 
His saying: (AND WOUNDING TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER MODIFICATION IF IT IS ISSUED EXPLAINED BY ONE WHO KNOWS ITS CAUSES. IF IT IS DEVOID OF MODIFICATION: IT IS ACCEPTED GENERALLY, ACCORDING TO THE CHOSEN VIEW): If wounding and modification conflict, there are two cases:
• Case One: They conflict and the reason is not mentioned; modification takes precedence.
• Case Two: The reason is mentioned and it is a clear, explained, proven reason; wounding takes precedence. If the reason is not mentioned or an unsupported reason is mentioned, one returns to modification. 
He attributed this to the majority of scholars and preferred it. This is extremely useful in many disputes that occur regarding some men. A scholar might say: "This one is a partisan (Hizbi)," or "innovator," or "misguided," with a general wound, while others authenticated him. The word of that man is not accepted unless with two conditions:
• Condition One: That he be known for moderation, knowledge, cognizance, justice, and fairness.
• Condition Two: That he mentions his evidence for this. If he brings evidence, fine; otherwise, it is not accepted.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - said: CHAPTER. AND IT IS IMPORTANT: TO KNOW THE KUNYAS OF THOSE NAMED, AND THE NAMES OF THOSE KNOWN BY KUNYAS, AND WHOSE NAME IS HIS KUNYA, AND WHOSE KUNYA IS DISPUTED, AND WHO HAS MANY KUNYAS OR DESCRIPTIONS, AND WHOSE KUNYA AGREES WITH HIS FATHER'S NAME, OR VICE VERSA, OR HIS KUNYA IS HIS WIFE'S KUNYA, AND WHO IS ATTRIBUTED TO OTHER THAN HIS FATHER, OR TO HIS MOTHER, OR TO OTHER THAN WHAT COMES TO MIND, AND WHOSE NAME AND FATHER'S AND GRANDFATHER'S NAME AGREE, OR HIS SHEIKH'S NAME AND HIS SHEIKH'S SHEIKH'S NAME AND UPWARDS. AND WHOSE SHEIKH'S NAME AND THE NARRATOR FROM HIM AGREE. AND KNOWLEDGE OF ABSTRACT AND SINGULAR NAMES, KUNYAS, TITLES, AND LINEAGES. THEY OCCUR RELATING TO TRIBES AND HOMELANDS: LANDS, OR FARMS, OR ALLEYS, OR PROXIMITY; AND TO CRAFTS AND TRADES. AGREEMENT AND RESEMBLANCE OCCUR IN THEM LIKE NAMES, AND THEY MAY OCCUR AS TITLES. AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE CAUSES OF THAT. AND KNOWLEDGE OF CLIENTS (MAWALI) FROM ABOVE AND FROM BELOW: BY SLAVERY, OR BY ALLIANCE. AND KNOWLEDGE OF BROTHERS AND SISTERS. AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE MANNERS OF THE SHEIKH AND STUDENT, AND THE AGE OF ENDURANCE AND PERFORMANCE, AND THE MANNER OF WRITING HADITH, ITS PRESENTATION, HEARING IT, RECITING IT, TRAVELING FOR IT, AND CLASSIFYING IT: EITHER ON MASANID, OR CHAPTERS, OR ILLS (ILAL), OR PARTS (ATRAF). AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE CAUSE OF HADITH: SOME SHEIKHS OF JUDGE ABU YA'LA IBN AL-FARRA' WROTE ON IT. THEY WROTE ON MOST OF THESE TYPES. THEY ARE PURE TRANSMISSION, APPARENT IN DEFINITION, NEEDING NO EXAMPLES, AND ENUMERATING THEM IS DIFFICULT: SO LET THEIR DETAILED WORKS BE REVIEWED. AND ALLAH IS THE GRANTER OF SUCCESS AND THE GUIDE, THERE IS NO GOD BUT HIM. 
Everything mentioned previously regarding knowledge of Kunyas and Lineages... etc., was extremely important in the past. But after the existence of books facilitated by indexes alphabetically and otherwise, then electronic libraries, we do not need to memorize this; because as soon as you encounter a man you need to check, you return to these books. Beware of relying on your memory, for memory is treacherous. Ali bin al-Madini said: My master Ahmed bin Hanbal ordered me not to narrate except from a book, for memory is treacherous. Some, when they see a chain and want to judge it, become lax and say: In the chain is Hisham bin Hassan who is trustworthy, narrating from Al-Hasan Al-Basri who is trustworthy... etc., so the hadith is authentic. His action is wrong and lax, for there is no doubt Hisham bin Hassan is trustworthy, but from Al-Hasan Al-Basri he is weak.

book_title: Idamat al-Nazar fi Tahrir Nukhbat al-Fikar
text:
Similarly, one might see the 'An'anah' of Ibn Jurayj and reject it because he is a Mudallis, which is true, but his narration in the chain might be from Ata', and Ibn Jurayj's narration from Ata' is accepted even if he uses 'An', for he does not practice Tadlis from Ata'. Such matters are not known except by referring to biographical books. So the student must expand, and it is not sufficient to refer to the book *Taqrib al-Tahdhib*; although useful for knowing Al-Hafiz's summary judgment, we treat it like other scholars' judgments to reach a conclusion. I emphasize: Beware of relying on memory. Even if assumed the men are trustworthy, it remains: did they hear from each other or not? Then if assumed they heard from each other, it remains: did the early Hafizs criticize this text or not? For in some hadiths, a student hears from his Sheikh except this specific hadith he did not hear from him. Examples include the hadith of Tashahhud; Al-Nasa'i narrated from Ibn Masud that he said: "We used to stand before the Tashahhud was obligated upon us..." The chain appears authentic, and many late scholars concurred on authenticating it, except that Imam Ahmed clarified in *Al-Ilal* that Sufyan bin Uyainah did not hear it from his Sheikh. This is a subtle defect that only becomes clear by referring to books of Ilal (Defects). So looking at the trustworthiness of narrators is not enough; one must return to books of Ilal. 
As for Manners (Adab), it is extremely important. The student of knowledge should strive to acquire manners and not be content with the habits he was raised on. He should read books of manners like *Adab al-Talab* to beautify and improve himself with manners. We are in dire need of manners, whether we are old or young. We continue to read on manners and learn manners to beautify ourselves with manners, like manners of learning, manners of seeking, etc. I ask Allah to beautify us with manners and improve our character, O Lord of the Worlds. 
His saying: (AND THE AGE OF ENDURANCE [TAHAMMUL] AND PERFORMANCE [ADA']): There is a difference between Endurance and Performance. According to the most correct scholarly views, if a narrator is discerning (Mumayyiz), his endurance is valid. Even if he was a disbeliever, his endurance is valid, but his performance is not accepted until after Islam, and that is after puberty. So one must differentiate between the age of endurance and the age of performance. 
His saying: (AND THE MANNER OF WRITING HADITH, ITS PRESENTATION, HEARING IT, RECITING IT, TRAVELING FOR IT, AND CLASSIFYING IT: EITHER ON MASANID, OR CHAPTERS, OR ILLS, OR PARTS): As for the manner of writing hadith, presenting it, hearing it, and reciting it, I think we do not need this as we are not in the time of writing hadith [manually like before].

text:
His saying: (TRAVELING FOR IT): Traveling for seeking knowledge is extremely useful, and it is a path to acquiring knowledge. Thus scholars were people of travel. However, it is desired for other than itself, not for itself. Imam Malik, the Imam of the World, was not known for travel because he was in Medina and people used to come to Medina, and he took knowledge from them. As for scholars known for travel like Imam Ahmed, Ibn Ma'in, Abu Hatim, and others, travel for knowledge is a great worship. Jabir traveled a month for one hadith as Al-Bukhari noted. It is a great worship, but I emphasize it is desired for other than itself, not for itself. 
His saying: (AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE CAUSE OF HADITH: SOME SHEIKHS OF JUDGE ABU YA'LA IBN AL-FARRA' WROTE ON IT): The cause of hadith is important in knowing the meaning of the hadith, but many causes are not authentic from the Prophet, peace be upon him. What is authentic among them is useful in knowing the meaning of the hadith, like causes of revelation in verses. 
His saying: (THEY WROTE ON MOST OF THESE TYPES. THEY ARE PURE TRANSMISSION, APPARENT IN DEFINITION, NEEDING NO EXAMPLES, AND ENUMERATING THEM IS DIFFICULT: SO LET THEIR DETAILED WORKS BE REVIEWED. AND ALLAH IS THE GRANTER OF SUCCESS AND THE GUIDE, THERE IS NO GOD BUT HIM): He spoke the truth, for scholars did not fall short, and they wrote many books in every art - may Allah have mercy on them broadly. 
I conclude by clarifying the Stance on Books of Terminology (Mustalah). Someone might say: You mentioned many errors mentioned by Terminology scholars, does this mean we leave them, abandon them, and fight them? It is said: No. We should be moderate in this matter, neither excessive nor negligent. We should not be like those who exaggerated in fighting Terminology books, praising their opposition and calling for not reading them. Nor, on the other hand, should we be among those who exaggerated in attachment to them, making them their path and beacon. Rather, we should be as the people of knowledge were, making annotations/critiques. So read Terminology books, understand them, and clarify the error, without excess or negligence. For they contain treasures and benefits that only Allah knows. I ask Allah to forgive us all, and to make this explanation an argument for us not against us, and I ask Allah to forgive Hafiz Ibn Hajar - may Allah have mercy on him - and to gather me, you, him, and our parents in the Highest Paradise, O Lord of the Worlds.
